Posts.Content: Thanks for the information, TMCM. Do try to wrangle treatment at best (most expert) cancer center within your travel radius. There is some decent medicine here in the Lower Rio Grande Valley, but MD Anderson in Houston was within a day's drive. We jumped on it with both feet. I was surprised when the Uro here called for a biopsy with PSA only 4, but the guy was right on. (Dude did use *really* firm pressure on the DRE, though; won't miss that at all.) Very best wishes, and keep us informed as things develop. - Shu

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: Frankly, I'd be astonished if anyone truly ever - in spite of what they or anyone else might say - returned to pre-operative erectile function. No matter how 'nerve sparing' the surgery, I just don't think those delicate tissues like getting jerked around and ripped out of their happy home. Pretty good recovery to an acceptable level within a few months, I could go along with. But back to pre-op level, I just don't see it. Anyhow, I think I had an excellent doc. With Gleason 3+4 going in there was no expected need to cut or remove any nerves. Six months post-op, spontaneous erections are near totally absent. It takes a while to get worked up, but when needed we can 'rise to the occasion' with just visual and tactile stimulation - no resort to pharmacutacles or mechanical means. That's my story, and I'm stickin' to it. Not bad for a 70 yr old dude.

Posts.Title: Erections Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Incidentally, and FWIW: erections, while always available and adequate when the need arose (so to speak) without resort to pharmaceutical or mechanical-device assistance, have also been well short of 'prize-winning' territory. This past week however, 14 months post-op, I was pleasingly surprised to awake several times to Morning Wood to rank well up on the Rockwell Hardness scale. In other news, the variety of pains in right groin, testicle, and inner thigh mostly subsided at 12 months post-op after I totally backed off trying to match the pre-op 10,000 daily meters on the Concept II rowing machine. (The groin area, site of two previous hernia repair scar tissue, was doubtless pried open again for the prostatectomy.) The ol' scrotum had been hanging dangerously low, so the last month I made it a point to sleep supine with rolled up towel between the legs keeping said appendage elevated above the crush zone. Perhaps healing just takes longer than we expect, but gets there eventually. Still far-and-away better than living with a constant subliminal nag 'when-am-i-gonna-do-something-about-this-cancer?'. - Shu

Posts.Title: What doctors are best at MD Anderson

Posts.Content: TMCM - Ouch! Plenty of 4+4 and 4+3 there in your assay. I'm thinking the next important question is: is/not the cancer still contained within the prostate. The CAT and bone scans should provide fairly reliable answer. Surgery is most appropriate if the cancer is still contained. Then removing the prostate removes all the cancer - excepting that cancer cells may have crept outside along nerve pathways in an amount too small to be detected at the time ("perineural invasion"). If some cancer has escaped but none has left the locality of the prostate, then a radiation treatment is perhaps more appropriate - maybe combined with some hormones to suppress growth. We are not medical professionals here, as you doubtless know, just folks with a very personal interest in prostate cancer. You should investigate all options, including treatment at a nationally ranked cancer center in Philly or beyond. Good news is prostate cancers grow slowly, but G=4+4 is serious business. If you care to share: your age, what prompted the biopsy, and had you been getting periodic PSA and DRE tests? Very best wishes to you - shu

Not sure about Outdoor's circumstances. Medicare and Tricare (military retired) paid the whole tab for me. I was just happy to be accepted there. Figured any- and every-body there was likely well qualified; any specific reports on individual surgeons would be anecdotal and not statistically significant. -Shu

Posts.Title: What doctors are best at MD Anderson

Posts.Content: Incidentally, and FWIW: erections, while always available and adequate when the need arose (so to speak) without resort to pharmaceutical or mechanical-device assistance, have also been well short of 'prize-winning' territory. This past week however, 14 months post-op, I was pleasingly surprised to awake several times to Morning Wood to rank well up on the Rockwell Hardness scale. In other news, the variety of pains in right groin, testicle, and inner thigh mostly subsided at 12 months post-op after I totally backed off trying to match the pre-op 10,000 daily meters on the Concept II rowing machine. (The groin area, site of two previous hernia repair scar tissue, was doubtless pried open again for the prostatectomy.) The ol' scrotum had been hanging dangerously low, so the last month I made it a point to sleep supine with rolled up towel between the legs keeping said appendage elevated above the crush zone. Perhaps healing just takes longer than we expect, but gets there eventually. Still far-and-away better than living with a constant subliminal nag 'when-am-i-gonna-do-something-about-this-cancer?'. - Shu

Posts.Title: New to the club

Posts.Content: TMCM - Ouch! Plenty of 4+4 and 4+3 there in your assay. I'm thinking the next important question is: is/not the cancer still contained within the prostate. The CAT and bone scans should provide fairly reliable answer. Surgery is most appropriate if the cancer is still contained. Then removing the prostate removes all the cancer - excepting that cancer cells may have crept outside along nerve pathways in an amount too small to be detected at the time ("perineural invasion"). If some cancer has escaped but none has left the locality of the prostate, then a radiation treatment is perhaps more appropriate - maybe combined with some hormones to suppress growth. We are not medical professionals here, as you doubtless know, just folks with a very personal interest in prostate cancer. You should investigate all options, including treatment at a nationally ranked cancer center in Philly or beyond. Good news is prostate cancers grow slowly, but G=4+4 is serious business. If you care to share: your age, what prompted the biopsy, and had you been getting periodic PSA and DRE tests? Very best wishes to you - shu

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: Frankly, I'd be astonished if anyone truly ever - in spite of what they or anyone else might say - returned to pre-operative erectile function. No matter how 'nerve sparing' the surgery, I just don't think those delicate tissues like getting jerked around and ripped out of their happy home. Pretty good recovery to an acceptable level within a few months, I could go along with. But back to pre-op level, I just don't see it. Anyhow, I think I had an excellent doc. With Gleason 3+4 going in there was no expected need to cut or remove any nerves. Six months post-op, spontaneous erections are near totally absent. It takes a while to get worked up, but when needed we can 'rise to the occasion' with just visual and tactile stimulation - no resort to pharmacutacles or mechanical means. That's my story, and I'm stickin' to it. Not bad for a 70 yr old dude.

Posts.Title: 8 years post SRT

Posts.Content: Welcome, Felix - I'm thinking that most folks who go for the surgery do so because: ..If PSA drops to and remains at undetectable (after pre-operation existing hormone diminishes) there is very good assurance that no prostate cells exist anywhere in the body and all cancer removed; ..the whole prostate is available for pathology review. If it is known that the cancer has escaped and is well spread to distant sites, then removing the prostate may have no great affect on survival time, but just slaps the body with more insult to handle during treatment with hormones, radiation, etc. Your numbers of Gleason 6, PSA 4.0, 9 of 12 cores positive, suggest good prospect for containment in the prostate, and time available for study and decision; no need to panic. A DRE, digital rectal examination to check for palpable bumps on the prostate would provide helpful information. Sorry, have no links to statistical sites to offer. Numbers are interesting but often hide as much as they reveal. Every case is different, so should your decision be - to fit your physical and mental state, not shucked off on running some numbers. Very best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: 20 days post surgery

Posts.Content: Best advice I've seen is: get a small box of kiddy diapers - about 3 yr old, I think it was. Cut them in half amid-ships, gun'll to gun'll. Now you have two 'ballcatcher' pads. They will be bulkier than all but the heaviest adult diapers, but less expensive. Your guy will be wearing lose pants for a while anyhow. By the time you work through these, you'll have a better idea of what you really need. A lot of variables - how good the surgeon is, how bad the cancer was, the particular patient, etc. Everyone is different, but if the outcome is good you'll have avoided over-buying on incontinence supplies. - Shu

Posts.Title: Best post surgery pads

Posts.Content: I've said it before (August 2013, my visit w/ Dr. daVinci) and I'll say it again: "We hit the gate just right." ..just short of age 70 where some treatment options go off the table; ..having got most of the use out of the ol' gland; and ..(without getting too political) before what we saw as impending chaos in US medicine. With a maternal grandfather, father, paternal uncle, and older brother diagnosed with PC, I'd started an annual DRE and PSA at age 45. I tell that to my kids, and ain't too shy to mention it to any other male of that age. 'Nuf to make a strong man weep, seeing folks first post on the board here: "I / my husband / my Dad didn't know what a PSA was, but we just had a biopsy and it's G:4+4=8." </rant> - shu

Posts.Title: Editorial: Bad Prostate Cancer Advice

Posts.Content: Sandra - Welcome to the forum. Exactly as others have said. It is too soon to panic. The time now is for learning about prostate cancer generally, and testing to determine the nature of your Dad's particular cancer. If the cancer is still within the prostate gland, the situation is entirely fixable by either surgery to remove the gland, or a variety of radiation treatments to kill it in place. Even if there is some slight escape through the margin of the prostate, salvage radiation after surgery may be effective in fixing that. If the cancer has widely spread from the prostate, it is unfortunately a matter of pushing back the tumor growth rate and management of symptoms. IF it comes to that, there are several contributing here who are on that path - or are wives, daughters, or sons of a guy in treatment. Wilde makes an excellent point. Once cancer is confirmed by a biopsy, it is ill advised to spend time in pursuit of ineffective "treatments. Diet, exercise, and good attitude all contribute to avoiding cancer and to getting through a treatment regimen. But NONE of them, alone or in combination, will "cure" cancer. Stay calm, get informed, learn the results of the biopsy and scans, help your Dad make an informed choice regarding available treatments. Our very best wishes to you and your Dad - shu

Posts.Title: Dad detected with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Sandra - Welcome to the forum. Exactly as others have said. It is too soon to panic. The time now is for learning about prostate cancer generally, and testing to determine the nature of your Dad's particular cancer. If the cancer is still within the prostate gland, the situation is entirely fixable by either surgery to remove the gland, or a variety of radiation treatments to kill it in place. Even if there is some slight escape through the margin of the prostate, salvage radiation after surgery may be effective in fixing that. If the cancer has widely spread from the prostate, it is unfortunately a matter of pushing back the tumor growth rate and management of symptoms. IF it comes to that, there are several contributing here who are on that path - or are wives, daughters, or sons of a guy in treatment. Wilde makes an excellent point. Once cancer is confirmed by a biopsy, it is ill advised to spend time in pursuit of ineffective "treatments. Diet, exercise, and good attitude all contribute to avoiding cancer and to getting through a treatment regimen. But NONE of them, alone or in combination, will "cure" cancer. Stay calm, get informed, learn the results of the biopsy and scans, help your Dad make an informed choice regarding available treatments. Our very best wishes to you and your Dad - shu

Posts.Title: The waiting is brutal...

Posts.Content: Don't know. I had rt inguinal hernia repair at age 5, Lt. side at age 17, and both sides re-done about 2001. Then the area got worked over again last year with the prostatectomy. Some sharp single pains, like a pinch or needle poke, was something I had after the laproscopic work in 2001, but not after the prostatectomy. I put it down to surgical staples inside. Several times - every three or four months for a couple of years after the 2001 surgery, I would lift something wrong, or twist while lifting, and swear I'd sprung another hernia. But no, two or three weeks avoiding heavy work, and whatever was torn loose seemed to heal back. Actually it was about 1 year before I could sit for a long period without discomfort, and two years before I felt no more random pains or other problems. Same thing after the prostatectomy. Eight months out I thought I was cast iron again, and pushed up to 10 kilometers daily on the Concept 2 rowing machine. Then groin pains, rt testicle swelling, etc. Totally left off the rowing machine for two months, got an ultrasound of the area, and it's almost back to normal. Started ten days ago back on the rower with 2K, up to 6K now. Just don't push it, Steve. Gotta give it some time.

Posts.Title: hernia at incision site

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cancerinoregon Now he's taking the SP only. I am worried though. Can the SP actually kill cancer cells in time, not just reduce the hormone? They never gave him the option of hormone therapy because his hormones were fine I guess. I had read that the following are useful in killing cancer cells. Is this true? Welcome to the Board, Oregon - Keeping in mind that most of us, me specifically, are not medical professionals, I will say: ..Can Saw Palmetto kill cancer cells? No. ..Hormone therapy, as I understand it, is not used when hormones are out of balance but rather to purposely *un*balance hormone levels - to load up on female hormones, suppress prostatic activity, thus retard (but not kill) cancer growth rate. (That along with enlarged breasts, hot flashes, and the rest of it.) ..Are any of the following useful in killing cancer cells? No. That said, I see in the statistics a 70 yr old guy in generally good physical condition (better weight and body mass than myself), an elevated PSA, biopsy with four cores of G:3+3=6. (Not to say there is not something more dangerous that escaped sampling.) So, there is cancer there; but G:3+3=6 is not very aggressive. May well be your Dad will live many years and pass on due to some other cause without the known cancer ever becoming a real problem. Active Surveillance, as I understand the criteria, is not appropriate management because there are four cores and involvement on both sides. What your Dad is doing now, the Saw Palmetto "Cure", is better described as *in*active surveillance. At age 70, it's maybe a hard choice - to actively treat it or just let it go. For myself, at age 69.5 in good health with some G:3+4=7, we instantly went for surgical treatment. Takes all the worry out of it. Do encourage your Dad to get informed, get a more realistic grip on things, and make a better informed decision. And I'm thinking if he is going to get it treated, the sooner the better - not because of the G:3+3=6 (a concern but no cause for panic) but rather because at age 70 ability to tolerate treatment may start to decline steeply. My very best wishes to you and your Dad. - Shu

Posts.Title: Dad's biopsy results, looking for alternative treatment.

Posts.Content: Yeah, anxious waiting. Long hours of darkness (January in Sweden) probably does not help. For us, surgery in Houston was on a Monday, and the final pre-operation tests were the previous Friday. This actually worked out well. We are from a very small town. Just being in a big city, driving around, was enjoyable, relaxing, and distracting. We visited a museum, IKEA store (a new experience), bought plant we could not find at our local stores. If you can find some physical activity - a long walk perhaps, to distract the mind and tire the body, that might help. Otherwise, perhaps starting a good book. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Depressions, do you guys get them?

Posts.Content: That was my concern also. I'd had a double laproscopic hernia repair about 10 years prior. Also, one hernia repaired each side in my youth. MD Anderson hospital in Houston went ahead with the daVinci procedure. Surgeon said it took a little longer than the usual operation. IIRC he also said he found a couple of other weak areas and slapped some patches on. The prostatectomy was just over a year ago. The right groin area, right testicle, right inner thigh, etc. have been somewhat problematic - but that is the side that was most difficult with the hernias a decade ago. Same thing with this recovery - circulation pains develop if I sit too long (driving or at computer), and I tend to press the limits with working outside and on the exercise machine. Hope this helps. Best wishes, -shu

Posts.Title: Previous abdominal surgery and need to have prostate out

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side Function. Sounds like you had a good trip. It'll take a while for the gut to fill and start functioning. That first poop will be a YUGE relief. There is also a lot of gas (used to inflate a work space for the robot between skin and innards) which will migrate out through the gut. Remember the hydrocodone tends toward constipation, and you don't want that. Shoulder pain comes from being positioned head down and butt up on the operating table. Didn't find that myself, but a lot of the guys mentioned it. Best advice I saw on pads, which we followed, was get a small pack of kiddie diapers, about 3 yr old. Cut them in two, halfway between bow and stern. Cheaper than adult pads. First few days off the catheter you'll still be wearing loose pants and not going out in public much. By the time you work through those, you will have a better idea of what capacity and how many adult products to buy. I still have half a 50 ct box of drip pads on the closet shelf. - shu

Posts.Title: the catheter is out, get a cork!

Posts.Content: 'Bout like takin' a whizz. Nothing to worry about. Seriously, just the sensation of something moving thru the urethra. The interesting one was removal of the abdominal vacuum drainage bulb before discharge from the hospital. Fellow doing the job said: "When I tell you, I want you to say 'woooooooooo.'" He did, I did, and the sound covered the unusual sensation of the (quite long) drainage tube being pulled thru my innards. But the urinary catheter, that's not an unusual sensation, nor at all painful.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the other side Function. Sounds like you had a good trip. It'll take a while for the gut to fill and start functioning. That first poop will be a YUGE relief. There is also a lot of gas (used to inflate a work space for the robot between skin and innards) which will migrate out through the gut. Remember the hydrocodone tends toward constipation, and you don't want that. Shoulder pain comes from being positioned head down and butt up on the operating table. Didn't find that myself, but a lot of the guys mentioned it. Best advice I saw on pads, which we followed, was get a small pack of kiddie diapers, about 3 yr old. Cut them in two, halfway between bow and stern. Cheaper than adult pads. First few days off the catheter you'll still be wearing loose pants and not going out in public much. By the time you work through those, you will have a better idea of what capacity and how many adult products to buy. I still have half a 50 ct box of drip pads on the closet shelf. - shu

Posts.Title: and its done! I'm post-op

Posts.Content: 'Bout like takin' a whizz. Nothing to worry about. Seriously, just the sensation of something moving thru the urethra. The interesting one was removal of the abdominal vacuum drainage bulb before discharge from the hospital. Fellow doing the job said: "When I tell you, I want you to say 'woooooooooo.'" He did, I did, and the sound covered the unusual sensation of the (quite long) drainage tube being pulled thru my innards. But the urinary catheter, that's not an unusual sensation, nor at all painful.

Posts.Title: and its done! I'm post-op

Posts.Content: Cathy - You mention options, which I take to mean surgery vs. one of the several radiation treatments. Surgery is all I can speak to from personal experience, although father and elder brother did select a radiation treatment. My understanding is that "cure" rates (no detectable cancer at 5 years post treatment) are statistically the same for surgery and several of the radiation methods. Colateral effects, urinary incontinence and erectile function, are immediate after surgery - with recovery of both common as time passes. With radiation there are no immediate colateral effects - but they often do appear with the passage of time. You whack the prostate out and re-align the plumbing, yeah there's gonna be some urinary and erection problems right off. But barring unusual problems with the surgery, prospects are good once the shock of trauma wears off. It is major surgery. Expect to be out a few weeks from a desk job, maybe a couple of months if work is physical. With the prostate gone, PSA effectively zero at six weeks means you got it all out. You dose the area with radiation, yeah there's gonna be some tissue scarring. The scars may harden and grow over time, may cause some urinary and erectile problems. May be some scheduling problems with work during radiation treatments, but no major interferrence or time away. PSA dropping after radiation treatment means there is less cancer than before; time will tell. At least that's my take on it. For myself, we chose surgery ..for the certainty, after pathology of the prostate and the six week PSA test, of cure being effective; and ..because being retired, time away from work was not an issue. You can see from the signature block below that at six weeks post surgery we had no detectatble PSA, acceptable urinary control, and acceptable erectile function without pharmacutical assist. Hope this helps. Best wishes. - Shu

Posts.Title: RP questions

Posts.Content: Izzat what that is? Left foot had for many years retained more fluid than right, but after the prostatectomy they are equally bloated. Not painful, or even particularly annoying, but noticeable. Persons who have had varicose leg veins stripped (am well acquainted with one such person) have a similar problem. Compression stockings are available up to thigh height and in different compression grades. Larger selection from internet sources than your local pharmacy. Put them on in the morning before getting out of bed, or you have pretty much lost it for the day. Keep legs raised when/where possible during the day. Feet up on a foot-stool when seated. Lie down and raise legs for a rest. Sleep on back with legs on a large, firm pillow. Best wishes, Dog - shu.

Posts.Title: BRACHY REPORT...6 Months Out

Posts.Content: Something else, which I just discovered this evening. I had already learned that lying flat with the groin area opened up (e.g. right foot drawn up to left inner thigh, right knee laid out to the right side) feels good and seems to help drainage. This would be like the yoga "tree" position if done standing Wife and I had not done any yoga for a year or so, but for a while we were quite regular with Susan Winter Ward's program #1 of "Yoga for the Young at Heart." This evening I was trying some of the old stretches and breathing - all done lying on my back on a mat. Worked marvelous well for draining the scrotum. I'd go *very slowly* with this, especially so soon after surgery and if you have not done any yoga before. You just ease into ("toward" is probably a better word than "into") the positions, as far as your body wants to go, no forcing, no rapid moves, and breath fully and slowly for a few breaths. -shu

Posts.Content: Newbury - What the other guys said. Anything is possible, but with biopsy of G:3+3=6 and the low PSA, it would be a real outlier case not to be still confined in the prostate and totally fixable by prostatectomy from a competent surgeon. Just speaking from watching the traffic on the board here, and from personal experience. Best wishes - shu Oh, and there's that thing about "God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change ..."

Posts.Title: Due to have Radical Prostatectomy in 2 weeks

Posts.Content: Hi Fatherbuild. I'm 69 yrs old. Had robotic prostatectomy 19 Aug at MD Anderson in Houston. Pain in foot issue I cannot speak to, altho the damaged nerve possibility someone mentioned seems reasonable. Testicular swelling and groin pain, I can speak to. For background: about 2000 I had laproscopic repair of inguinal hernias (both sides). Swollen balls was a real problem - something I was not prepared for. I put this to inadequate briefing before the surgery. Makes sense that there will be a lot more fluid than usual in that region, that it will flow down-hill, and there aint much mechanism to pump it out. It did get better over time, but it was an effect of surgery I had not been mentally prepared to deal with. Also, it got *very* uncomfortable to sit at a desk or drive for more than 30 minutes at a time. The screen patches placed over the ruptured areas, and the swelling as tissue rebuilt around them, blocked circulation and I just could not stay folded for very long. This too got better with time, but it took months. It was about two years before I felt fully normal. Even so, every two or three years I will lift something too heavy, or make an unusual move with a shovel that stresses the area - the ol' scrotum starts to swell, and I need to be careful for a couple of weeks till things firm up again. Back to the present, for the first couple of weeks recovery from the DaVinci prostatectomy seemed to be a "piece of cake" compared to recovery from the hernia repairs. Some scrotal swelling, but I was ready for it this time. Then I got too bold and did something that pulled the groin area. So - I'm making a point to spend more time horizontal, stretch the legs out when seated, wear a jock strap over the shorts, and above all try to stifle urges to be "Mr. Strongman" around the house and yard. And, yes, it's getting better a bit every day. I don't know your Dad's age, his physical condition before surgery, or activity level after surgery. A qualified medical practitioner - *which I am not* - would have to determine if there is a condition needing surgical or other intervention. But lacking that, with patience and giving his bod. the rest it needs, it all should get better with time. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Post radical laparoscopic prostatectomy concerns

Posts.Content: Checked this thread before the trip to Houston (300 miles) for the 6 week post-op visit (and return the next day). Could be the relief of the Doc pressing around on the area and pronouncing nothing torn; could be the enforced reduced activity during the trip; could be news of the PSA reading, <0.1 ... but next day after returning home I was walking a lot better, not having to hold my balls in my hand going from place-to-place around the house. So - I'm gonna give a nod to Fairwind for the post above this, and write me some new rules: ....1) indeed, working the inner thigh muscles in walking may have pumping action that helps clear out accumulated fluid. so walk; ....2) any lifting, especially while turning or reaching, any action more vigorous than walking, may set the recovery back and reduce the sustainable pace from a stride to a slow shuffle; ....3) if that happens, just cowboy up and refer to rule 1). Oh. And if any of the boys have need of a guy with good DaVinci fingers, you can go to MD Anderson in Houston and look up Dr. John Davis. We caught this in time so he had a lot to work with, but I gotta say both bladder control and erectile function are "astonishing" - well above what I was prepared to accept. -shu

Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: Checked this thread before the trip to Houston (300 miles) for the 6 week post-op visit (and return the next day). Could be the relief of the Doc pressing around on the area and pronouncing nothing torn; could be the enforced reduced activity during the trip; could be news of the PSA reading, <0.1 ... but next day after returning home I was walking a lot better, not having to hold my balls in my hand going from place-to-place around the house. So - I'm gonna give a nod to Fairwind for the post above this, and write me some new rules: ....1) indeed, working the inner thigh muscles in walking may have pumping action that helps clear out accumulated fluid. so walk; ....2) any lifting, especially while turning or reaching, any action more vigorous than walking, may set the recovery back and reduce the sustainable pace from a stride to a slow shuffle; ....3) if that happens, just cowboy up and refer to rule 1). Oh. And if any of the boys have need of a guy with good DaVinci fingers, you can go to MD Anderson in Houston and look up Dr. John Davis. We caught this in time so he had a lot to work with, but I gotta say both bladder control and erectile function are "astonishing" - well above what I was prepared to accept. -shu

Posts.Title: A wife with questions

Posts.Content: Welcome aboard, Mrs. GG. The numbers look very promising for a complete removal of the cancer with the prostate. Yes, PNI is an item of "awareness" or "interest" - but not at the level of "concern," and certainly well short of "panic." Nice thing about the surgery treatment path is the whole gland - and usually some surrounding tissue - goes to the pathology lab, so you get a good reading on the situation. Many of us seem to overbuy on incontinence products. Ain't a big worry. Someone on the forum about the time I was going thru the process suggested get a box of large baby diapers, cut them in half (midway between bow and stern) and you will have two absorbent pads. Before you work your way through that pack, you will have a better idea of what you need. I've still got the major part of a box of 50 drip pads on the closet shelf. With any luck, a couple of weeks after catheter removal (say three weeks out from D day) when Hubby is feeling spry enough for lengthy times away from the house, he may just need to stick a couple of spare drip pads in his pocket. Light, loose fitting pants are nice to have for the first couple of weeks after D day. Maybe a string tie or elastic at the waist rather than belt, and legs loose enough to hide the catheter ankle bag. Whatever. As regards personal stats: If you wish, you can click "Settings" at upper right of main panel, then "Edit Signature" along the left margin of the Settings window. Best wishes to you both. - Shu

Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: Hey Wheeler - Thanks for the sharing. Keeps the board alive. I had also had previous hernia repairs - one side age 5, other side age 17, both sides again (laproscopic surgery) about age 60. This was a concern when we got the biopsy news. I believe the robotic procedure is favored over open where there are prior hernia repairs. My own recovery from the prostatectomy, as to healing and pains in the groin area, seems to have been more troublesome than most folks on the forum here, but them's the cards I was dealt and it seems mostly stabilized after a year. Nice news on the Gleason downgrade. (It ain't every day we're happy to see one of our scores lowered!) Best wishes - shu

Posts.Content: Fran - Welcome aboard. As Chuck said, that is an uncommon issue, but should not be unique. There should be an answer available. By "internal examination" do you mean the DRE (digital rectal exam - finger-up-the-butt) or biopsy (tissue samples taken by injection needle thru intestinal wall into prostate)? If you are close to one of the large medical centers like MD Anderson in Houston, the Mayo Clinic, etc., perhaps it's time to call in the heavy hitters. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: My first post-surgery PSA report is in

Posts.Content: Hey, FedCav. Good to hear from you. Yeah, water doesn't run uphill you know. Whatever mechanism the body has for moving fluids out of the testicles has to work against all that abdominal swelling now. It'll get much better over the next week or 10 days. You can roll up a small towel between your legs for Larry and Roger to lie on while you sleep. When the abdominal swelling goes down you may want to dig through your sock drawer for that old jock strap. For me, it was not as bad as after the double laproscopic hernia repair in 2000. Still have some problems there because of all the hernia work and the prostatectomy on top of it. Anyhow, you say they likely got all the bad stuff out, so your major worry now is Bedford Forrest. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Content: Not an easy call. I'd give top pick to what Wife is used to driving. Won't be as easy to get in and out of as the F250, but do-able. You'll want to lay the seat back once you get in, as you will still be well bloated in lower abdomen. If you must sit folded at the waist, doing so for more than an hour straight may go from discomfort to bordering on medical issues. Alternatively, if Son is in town and comfortable pushing the F250 ... Just my take on it. Best wishes tomorrow. - Shu

Posts.Title: Post-op vehicle choice?

Posts.Content: That's a gnarly one, 2Fury. Twentyseven is just too young. But, there it is. The biopsy results seem valid. You asked "...what would yall recommend?" Most of us are older. Heck. ALL of us are older than 27. It's hard for me at 70 with the oldest grandchild getting ready for college, to put myself mentally back at 27. But I think the answer is the same. Given that the biopsy is correct, there are three paths available. ..Ignore the problem. Forget about it. Enjoy the life you are living now. Statistically, it's likely to be relatively short and end with bone cancer. ..Resolve to deal with the problem at some future time. Put off the decision. Some folks can handle this better than others. Might find you spend a lot of time worrying about it, obsessing over PSA readings - was that change because of a different lab tech, something you did or ate yesterday? Wait long enough, and a new miracle cure might be found, altho the major treatment paths available now are technically well developed. Wait too long, and you've missed the boat entire. ..Resolve to treat the cancer now. Yeah, the treatment will take time, and life will be different after, but at least there won't be that cancer to worry about. Of the usual treatments, ....prostatectomy will be a harsh month or so, pretty much back to all activities in six months, good prospects for urinary control and erections (but no ejaculate). ....radiation will be a longer course of treatment; you'll keep all your 'nads, but good chance of erectile problems developing later. ....hormones, etc. - can't speak to; I know nothing. I think healthwise - speaking both mental and physical health - I'd make the same decision at 27 as I did at 69. The hard part is the kids issue. There are ways around it - banking sperm, as you say, or adoption. Hang in there, kid. -shu (F4 Phantoms, DaNang, 1967-

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer at 27 years old

Posts.Content: Welcome aboard S.R. Most folks here on the forum don't put much stock in diet as a treatment for a known cancer. Funnin' around with what you eat as a cancer preventative is maybe OK, but once the biopsy shows it's there, then the fun stops and you best be looking at serious medically proven methods for *treatment*. Moderator may tell you them's kinda the rules for discussion on this particular board. The stats you report do call for serious treatment. Most guys here, as it happens, seem to opt for surgery. Radiation is effective, statistically about the same as surgery if caught in time, and many do go that route. Surgery removes the prostate for a detailed pathology report. With the prostate gone, an undetectable PSA level points to no cancer escaped or left behind. These are mental comfort features that radiation treatments do not provide. Very best wishes to you in the treatment you select. - shu

Posts.Title: One year out: still good

Posts.Content: That's a gnarly one, 2Fury. Twentyseven is just too young. But, there it is. The biopsy results seem valid. You asked "...what would yall recommend?" Most of us are older. Heck. ALL of us are older than 27. It's hard for me at 70 with the oldest grandchild getting ready for college, to put myself mentally back at 27. But I think the answer is the same. Given that the biopsy is correct, there are three paths available. ..Ignore the problem. Forget about it. Enjoy the life you are living now. Statistically, it's likely to be relatively short and end with bone cancer. ..Resolve to deal with the problem at some future time. Put off the decision. Some folks can handle this better than others. Might find you spend a lot of time worrying about it, obsessing over PSA readings - was that change because of a different lab tech, something you did or ate yesterday? Wait long enough, and a new miracle cure might be found, altho the major treatment paths available now are technically well developed. Wait too long, and you've missed the boat entire. ..Resolve to treat the cancer now. Yeah, the treatment will take time, and life will be different after, but at least there won't be that cancer to worry about. Of the usual treatments, ....prostatectomy will be a harsh month or so, pretty much back to all activities in six months, good prospects for urinary control and erections (but no ejaculate). ....radiation will be a longer course of treatment; you'll keep all your 'nads, but good chance of erectile problems developing later. ....hormones, etc. - can't speak to; I know nothing. I think healthwise - speaking both mental and physical health - I'd make the same decision at 27 as I did at 69. The hard part is the kids issue. There are ways around it - banking sperm, as you say, or adoption. Hang in there, kid. -shu (F4 Phantoms, DaNang, 1967-

Posts.Title: Surgery Day Soon and Right Mind Set

Posts.Content: What they said. I would think at four weeks, certainly, there would be sufficient internal healing; so no danger of injury. Should not be any pain. There likely will be emission from the Cowpers glands (the slippery pre-cum). Climacturia (ejaculation of urine) may (or not) be an issue. I'm sure that if the matter is taken in hand, your questions can be answered. My experience, sex after prostatectomy is a little slower and a lot less messy. - Shu

Posts.Title: Sex after RP

Posts.Content: Bravehardon #7 above. True. A lot of surgeons out there with prostatectomy operation counts over 1,000. Since most of us have only one prostate, it would follow there is a large number of men who have had prostate removal surgery. Add in the number of radiation patients. Consider that prostate cancer is the most common type among males. Shucks. Could be another guy on your same block; half dozen or more in a large apartment complex. But they're all trying to keep it a secret? And, yes, it does get easier with the passage of time to share - often beginning with anonymous sharing on a web forum. My suggestion, wear it like a badge of honor. Happen to meet an old High School chum or co-worker, drop a remark in: "BTW. I had to leave my prostate in Houston last year. If you ain't getting a poke in the butt and PSA check once a year, you should be." - Shu

Posts.Title: Radiation 2.5 years after prostectomy... Questions

Posts.Content: Hello ddl - Your biopsy results are close to my own, altho I have more years on. You mention Texas. When the local urologist delivered the biopsy news, he said ..bone scan or other tests for metastasis not recommended, as biopsy suggested cancer detected early and contained; ..some form of treatment was indicated, either radiation or surgery, surgery being either open or robotic; ..we were welcome to look for a second opinion on the biopsy, MD Anderson in Houston sometimes would do that. At that point, wife and I looked at eachother. MDA is 300 miles away but we had been there before, for another problem. We thanked the doc and left to wangle a referral for a daVinci procedure at MDA. Waited a few weeks for the initial appointment and review, another trip with a week's reservation at the Rotary House for the operation, and a third trip back for the six week post-op review. As Zdog mentioned in a recent post, if we needed to hit the gate we felt we hit it just right. G:3+4=7 is past the 3+3=6 agonizing decision cusp, but well in the statistical range for complete capture. Plus, we had got most of the use we needed out of the gland, at just short of age 70 (where some treatment options begin to be withdrawn) and in Aug 2013 just short of the chaos we saw on the horizon due to nationalization of health insurance. Literature the surgeon at MDA provided indicated success rates (total eradication of cancer) at five years were similar for radiation and surgery, but surgery provided two prognostic indicators: ..the entire gland and surrounding tissue would be available for pathology; ..if the cancer had not spread, the PSA should drop to and remain 'undetectable'. It worked well for us. YMMV. Best wishes, -shu

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Kent - Chill, Bro. Anything's possible, but with just one out of twelve showing positive, probably G6, and the Doc suggesting Active Surveillance as appropriate, it's way more likely whatever you have is still contained in the prostate. Hey, you're past fifty, Dude. You gonna start picking up some joint pains. Review the biopsy results, get a PSA and finger poke regularly - whatever you work out with the Docs. You should make at least a Plan A for treatment (surgery or radiation) and set trigger points (maybe appearance of a Gleason 7 core) for activating that plan, but we don't see any reason to short yourself on sleep tonight. Oh - and Welcome Aboard. - Shu Ron G - Urologist who did my biopsy said "sometimes we do a bone scan, but I don't think one is necessary here." MD Anderson, which did the surgery, did not do any scans either. I don't know what their decisions were based on - number of positive cores, location of cores, looking at pathology slides?? Maybe MD Anderson thought "we're gonna take it out in a month anyhow, we can look at the margins then." I do see, in the threads here, bone scans seem to be done well more often than not. Maybe it's just the Doc's wanting to be safe, or establish a base-line.

Posts.Title: Vacation question

Posts.Content: Greetings, Glock19. Didn't notice any age reference in yr profile, but will take it as correct you are 70. If you are in good physical condition, surgery is certainly do-able. Mine was at 69 1/2. Whole prostate comes out for a complete pathology report. Only problem post-surgery (aside from the occasional dribble of urine, and dry orgasms) was circulation in groin area and drainage from testicles. I'd had several hernia repairs, and the prostatectomy doc said he found and patched a few more. The major cure for that was giving up my favored Concept2 aerobic rower and getting their stand-up SkiErg. Made the problem manageable. Oh, and G26 is my carry. Shoulder holster is appropriate for a while post-surgery. Very best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Vacation question

Posts.Content: Hello Function. Full Disclosure: this particular Forum does seem to lean toward surgery as primaryl treatment. (Thankfully we have contributors who go with radiation, ASAdvocate, and guys with recurrence issues to keep me on top of things.) You noted one of the +points for surgery; I assume you are aware of others: full assay of the cancer by the pathologist, confident test for clean catch by PSA drop to undetectable, etc. As you noted (and experience of my Father and brothers confirm) radiation effects show up later. Return to work at two weeks may be a bit optimistic - IF you have a short commute, have a desk job, don't mind shuffling rather than walking swiftly, and are willing to get up and walk around every 30-40 minutes. Return at 4 weeks is more realistic. Prostatectomy is serious surgery (well, cancer is a serious disease!!) and there are those aboard the Forum who have had recovery issues. Wilde and (IIRC) DogDollar come to mind. That said (and I don't say this often, knock on wood) I was just short of age 70 at surgery; at the 6 week follow up I went with maybe just a drip pad in the skivies and had serviceable erections. I think this is close to the common recovery trajectory. As to urinary continence we lose the sphincter near the prostate, but have in reserve a sphincter in the pelvic floor muscles. That is how the ladies are plumbed, so how bad can that be. We just need to learn to use it. Erectile function is more problematic. Depends on what the surgeon finds when he goes in, and the quality of his "hands." At Gleason 8, were I you, I'd cut that sucker out and be thankful for whatever followed. Very best wishes to you, Function. Do stay on board and keep us informed. - shu

Posts.Title: Not new, but new here.

Posts.Content: Hello Function. Full Disclosure: this particular Forum does seem to lean toward surgery as primaryl treatment. (Thankfully we have contributors who go with radiation, ASAdvocate, and guys with recurrence issues to keep me on top of things.) You noted one of the +points for surgery; I assume you are aware of others: full assay of the cancer by the pathologist, confident test for clean catch by PSA drop to undetectable, etc. As you noted (and experience of my Father and brothers confirm) radiation effects show up later. Return to work at two weeks may be a bit optimistic - IF you have a short commute, have a desk job, don't mind shuffling rather than walking swiftly, and are willing to get up and walk around every 30-40 minutes. Return at 4 weeks is more realistic. Prostatectomy is serious surgery (well, cancer is a serious disease!!) and there are those aboard the Forum who have had recovery issues. Wilde and (IIRC) DogDollar come to mind. That said (and I don't say this often, knock on wood) I was just short of age 70 at surgery; at the 6 week follow up I went with maybe just a drip pad in the skivies and had serviceable erections. I think this is close to the common recovery trajectory. As to urinary continence we lose the sphincter near the prostate, but have in reserve a sphincter in the pelvic floor muscles. That is how the ladies are plumbed, so how bad can that be. We just need to learn to use it. Erectile function is more problematic. Depends on what the surgeon finds when he goes in, and the quality of his "hands." At Gleason 8, were I you, I'd cut that sucker out and be thankful for whatever followed. Very best wishes to you, Function. Do stay on board and keep us informed. - shu

Posts.Title: post-surgery experiences

Posts.Content: Welcome to the Other Side, RedBull. Coughing is probably due to the breathing tube inserted down the throat during the time under anesthetic. My first request when I woke up: "Can I get some ice to suck on?" From the attendant's response I think there was some hesitancy. Wanted to be sure I could swallow well before giving me anything that might cause choking. Hopefully it will clear up for you after a while. Some green tea with honey and a bit of lemon, maybe? Just take it easy; don't push returning to normal activity level too soon. Let the healing come to you. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Sex after DaVinci--Houston, we have liftoff!

Posts.Content: Kerry - My recommendation: back off and take it easy for a while. 2 1/2 weeks post surgery is *way* too early for anything more strenuous than walking around. Seriously. I had laproscopic hernia repair (left and right) in 2001. Sitting in a normal office brought pain at the fold of the groin after a short time. This gradually got better, but it was a full year before I could sit normally for a long time. Two years before I felt fully back to normal. The daVinci operation a year ago was much the same, but not quite as severe. You can search up some of my posts on the forum, if you care to. Tissue layers in the lower abdomen were separated to create the operating cavity. They need to patch themselves together. Water don't normally run up-hill, ya know, and fluids are going to collect in the testicles, have a harder than usual time making it back up through the swollen groin. Yes, it does feel a lot like a hernia - same dull pain of restricted circulation. If you've had it checked by the doc and he says no hernia, than just back off and give it time to heal. Best wishes, - shu

Posts.Title: My Post-Op Pathology

Posts.Content: Remain calm, Flyhigh. While report of a nodule points to need of a biopsy, PSA reading is not alarming. Prostate cancers, if still contained within the gland, are entirely taken out with removal of the prostate. Although serious surgery, this is a very common operation. Plenty of highly skilled surgeons around. Alternatively (although it seems statistically a less chosen route by the folks on this particular Board) the cancer can be killed in place by various radiation methods. Check my stats below. We were a few months short of 70 when we "got the news." I previously had a couple of fits of irregular premature heartbeat lasting a few weeks - probably triggered by inadequate fluid intake and too much chainsaw work in the Texas summer sun. Get the biopsy. Read up on prostate cancer. A book by Dr. Walsh is recommended; plenty of stories on this Board. If tests show presence of cancer, make a decision for treatment. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: DRE Found Nodule on My Prostate

Posts.Content: Alpine - With a Gleason score of 7 and a palpable mass on the prostate, it is time for treatment by conventional means. Diet, clean living, etc. will have no meaningful effect on the progress of the disease. Hormone treatment may suppress growth of the tumor(s). Radiation (several treatment methods are available) can kill the tumor in place. Surgical removal of the prostate will remove a contained tumor and leave available the option of radiation treatment if it is later found some cancer cells were left behind. Although we are not medical practitioners, I think all on the Forum will agree that given the conditions you describe, it is time for serious action. Best wishes - Shu246

Posts.Title: PSA 59, Gleason 7, Biopsy 92% cancer in all lobes of prostrate. Still contained

Posts.Content: Presuming you will not be alone on this trip - that wife or someone will be accompanying and attending. I'll give a cautious vote for air travel, noting the lack of flexibility vs. car, and suggesting longer than "two extra days" at Baltimore. Correct about not sitting for long periods. Two hour flight time, plus the extra ramp time, should be do-able. First class seat and board last would be good. With air travel changing your return date can be a problem, and there are bag-drags at the airports. For us, MD Anderson at Houston is a 300 mile trip. We did not even consider air travel. Available surgery dates were Monday and Thursday (pre-dawn show-up) with some appointments the day prior. There is a hotel in the campus grounds, connected by skyways to the hospital. We picked the Monday surgery date and booked a kitchenet room for a Thursday arrival, through Wednesday (13 nights, just to be extra cautious). Made an appointment with the local Urologist on D+9 for catheter removal. Pre-op appointments Friday; Saturday to sight-see around Houston; Sunday for tending to the bowel purge routine and fasting. I took two nights (Monday, Tuesday) in the hospital - perhaps because of my age or more surgery problems for the Doc to work with prior hernia repairs. Wednesday morning I was slouching around hanging onto a spare IV tree or pushing a wheel chair for support, and anxious to get back to the hotel room. By Friday I could slow-walk around the hospital grounds or local stores without looking or feeling like an idiot. (Bring some loose string-tie pants.) But I still had not had a bowel movement, was starting to feel rather packed up and a bit concerned. That finally came, with great relief, early hours Saturday. I felt ready to travel. It was early enough we could have left that day, but being old folks we took Saturday to slowly pack the car and rest. Wife did most of the work and all the driving, of course. Local Urologist removed the catheter on D+9 as scheduled, and I drove the 20 miles from his office back home. Best wishes to you, Logic. - Shu

I'll give a cautious vote for air travel, noting the lack of flexibility vs. car, and suggesting longer than "two extra days" at Baltimore. Correct about not sitting for long periods. Two hour flight time, plus the extra ramp time, should be do-able. First class seat and board last would be good. With air travel changing your return date can be a problem, and there are bag-drags at the airports. For us, MD Anderson at Houston is a 300 mile trip. We did not even consider air travel. Available surgery dates were Monday and Thursday (pre-dawn show-up) with some appointments the day prior. There is a hotel in the campus grounds, connected by skyways to the hospital. We picked the Monday surgery date and booked a kitchenet room for a Thursday arrival, through Wednesday (13 nights, just to be extra cautious). Made an appointment with the local Urologist on D+9 for catheter removal. Pre-op appointments Friday; Saturday to sight-see around Houston; Sunday for tending to the bowel purge routine and fasting. I took two nights (Monday, Tuesday) in the hospital - perhaps because of my age or more surgery problems for the Doc to work with prior hernia repairs. Wednesday morning I was slouching around hanging onto a spare IV tree or pushing a wheel chair for support, and anxious to get back to the hotel room. By Friday I could slow-walk around the hospital grounds or local stores without looking or feeling like an idiot. (Bring some loose string-tie pants.) But I still had not had a bowel movement, was starting to feel rather packed up and a bit concerned. That finally came, with great relief, early hours Saturday. I felt ready to travel. It was early enough we could have left that day, but being old folks we took Saturday to slowly pack the car and rest. Wife did most of the work and all the driving, of course. Local Urologist removed the catheter on D+9 as scheduled, and I drove the 20 miles from his office back home. Best wishes to you, Logic. - Shu

Posts.Title: 18 month results.

Posts.Content: Well found, Otago. Let's put that in bold print. None of these products or services are intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease Yenney - Please accept our condolence for your Dad's condition, and our best wishes for finding and keeping good health. A high PSA reading can point to the possibility of prostate cancer. Biopsy can confirm, with high (but not total) degree of certainty, presence or absence of cancer. Radiation (in several medically administered forms), hormone treatments, chemotherapy, and (in many cases) surgical removal of the prostate have been proven effective methods of suppressing or eliminating prostate cancers. Nutritional supplements, not so much. Our very best wishes to you and your Dad. - shu

Posts.Title: One year ago today, 7/27/15, my world changed

Posts.Content: Warrior - So sorry to hear this. Thoughts from a guy who was just short of age 70 at surgery, family business (copier sales & service) for several years, happiest with chainsaw, on tractor, or in front of computer. Penile discharge I cannot speak to, but definitely get it sorted out by his surgeon or urologist!!! Pain in groin and scrotum, yeah plenty of that. But let's put it in perspective. He is, as you say, about three months out of surgery. I had double laproscopic hernia repair about age 58. It was a full year before I could sit (computer or driving) for more than 45 minutes without intense and growing pain in the crease of the legs. Two years until that surgery was all a faded memory. The prostatectomy was easier in that regard, thank you, but still ... it's abdominal surgery, you gotta remember, and fluid (like in the testicles) does not ordinarily run uphill. The whole area has been worked over and everything is swollen and trying to find its place again. Blood and lymph passages up from the testicles and in the groin will be compressed. Roll up a towel and stick it between the legs at night to keep the stuff elevated, if it helps. Put on a jock strap over the undershorts in the day; night time too, if it helps. Don't be seated longer than 30-40 minutes without getting up and walking around a few minutes. Three years out from the prostatectomy, it's all ancient history. Unless....... Tried to tweek up the drag on the exercise machine a couple of weeks ago. Couple of days of that, and the twins commenced to get heavy and started getting tangled between the thighs. A few days with the jock strap on, and everybody's back in place. Then there is the part about being "an active type guy" and the restriction of lifting more than xx lb for yy weeks after surgery. Don't know about your Hubby, but some guys may tend to push the limits. Don't ask me to say more about that. As to your moniker of "Warrior" there was a single frame cartoon I remember from years ago. Crane has a frog in it's beak, trying to swallow it. Frog has hands around crane's neck trying to choke it. Caption is "Never Give Up!" Hope this helps, and wishing you and Hubby happier times ahead. - shu Oh, and kudos for pestering the guy about annual DRE and PSA. Really.

Posts.Title: Oh, glorious day!

Posts.Content: Ouch. Sad tail indeed. Hope it all works out for you. Yeah, yr balls are gonna get huge for a while. Water doesn't run up-hill, ya'know. The whole area down there has been worked over pretty well, and it'll be a few weeks before the normal mechanisms for moving fluids from the testicles get back to working well. IIRC the thing about the catheter is: there are many reasons for having/needing a catheter. If somebody just shows up in the ER and needs catheterization, and it is not mentioned that the patient had prostatectomy - the prostate removed and the bladder sutured back to the utrethra - the ER folks could unintentionally damage the surgery area. We haven't had much experience with hospitals, but we're finding that many places allow the spouse or close relative to stay overnight - may even offer some sheets and a blanket to make up a bed in the recliner in the room. And we're beginning to understand that even in the best hospitals, having a family member present 24 hrs is REALLY A GOOD IDEA. The staff, bless their hearts, have a lot to do I guess. Should start to get better for you soon. Here's hoping. =shu

Posts.Title: What nobody told before surgery

Posts.Content: Could be the reason they call you "Lucky" Pierre. Yes as Chuck said - and with the caveats that .. we are not medical practitioners, just folks who have crossed paths with prostate cancer, and .. all prostate cancer cases are different - PSA of 1.7 is well within normal range. Get a PSA blood test and DRE (digital rectal exam, aka finger up the butt) every year. I started checking at age 40 because of prostate cancers in both maternal and paternal lines. A free/total PSA test, done with the same blood draw, also provides information. Try to use the same lab every year. Keep track of the numbers and trends. Prostate cancers generally grow slowly. If treated before any cancer cells wander off to other parts of the body, prospect for complete "cure" is good. Just keep a watch on it. Check out my "signature" comments below. Best wishes, Pierre - Shu

Posts.Title: My PSA is 'undetectable' :)

Posts.Content: PSA is a blood test - unless there is something I don't know about. Urine sample is easy enough and likely collected routinely by urologists, but not used for PSA. There is another metric from the PSA blood sample that is of interest - the "free to total PSA ratio." For this, the higher the better. Above 25% is good news. Below 10% would be cause for concern. Trend of the numbers over time - both the total PSA and the F/T ratio - is helpful in pointing to possibility of cancer. For trending to be meaningful however, it is important that the analysis all be run by the same laboratory. These, along with DRE (digital rectal exam; finger poke) done yearly or more often if called for, are relatively inexpensive and non-invasive. The first tier diagnostic tools. Next level tool, more expensive and more invasive, is the biopsy. Good tool, but still a scattershot sample and could miss hitting an existing tumor. I could be wrong about this, but I'm thinking back pain or other "symptoms" are *not* helpful or reliable first indicators of prostate cancer. By the time back pain from prostate cancer is evident, the cancer is well out of the prostate and spread to the bones. I had for years a frequent need to urinate but without much production; kept pestering the Urologist about bladder infection etc. Finally figured it was due to nerves getting pinched by squashed discs in the lower back. That was decades before any detectable prostate cancer developed. When prostate cancer was found - as a result of yearly PSA and DRE monitoring, confirmed by biopsy - it was early enough for treatment with good chance of complete containment. Best wishes to you and yr guy. - Shu

Posts.Title: My PSA is 'undetectable' :)

Posts.Content: PSA is a blood test - unless there is something I don't know about. Urine sample is easy enough and likely collected routinely by urologists, but not used for PSA. There is another metric from the PSA blood sample that is of interest - the "free to total PSA ratio." For this, the higher the better. Above 25% is good news. Below 10% would be cause for concern. Trend of the numbers over time - both the total PSA and the F/T ratio - is helpful in pointing to possibility of cancer. For trending to be meaningful however, it is important that the analysis all be run by the same laboratory. These, along with DRE (digital rectal exam; finger poke) done yearly or more often if called for, are relatively inexpensive and non-invasive. The first tier diagnostic tools. Next level tool, more expensive and more invasive, is the biopsy. Good tool, but still a scattershot sample and could miss hitting an existing tumor. I could be wrong about this, but I'm thinking back pain or other "symptoms" are *not* helpful or reliable first indicators of prostate cancer. By the time back pain from prostate cancer is evident, the cancer is well out of the prostate and spread to the bones. I had for years a frequent need to urinate but without much production; kept pestering the Urologist about bladder infection etc. Finally figured it was due to nerves getting pinched by squashed discs in the lower back. That was decades before any detectable prostate cancer developed. When prostate cancer was found - as a result of yearly PSA and DRE monitoring, confirmed by biopsy - it was early enough for treatment with good chance of complete containment. Best wishes to you and yr guy. - Shu

Posts.Title: Made my choice today

Posts.Content: I've had two biopsies. First was about year 2000. It was endurable, but in no way pleasant. A carrier shroud for the spring-needle core collector was clipped over the ultrasound head (which was big enough allready, thank you!). Once inserted in the rectum, much maneuvering around to position for each sample shot. Twelves stabs in the prostate - and, yes, there are nerves there!. Mild shock after driving myself home; blood clots in ejaculate for a couple of weeks afterward. For the biopsy in 2013 the Uro. (different guy) suggested an anesthetic. I readily agreed. Tech from the hospital next door to the clinic came in. The knock-out was about on the level of colonoscopy - no consciousness, no pain, less after-shock than the first biopsy. The biopsy is necessary if you want the information it will provide, but something to be endured rather than enjoyed. I'd have done the second one without hesitation, but was glad when the Uro (unprompted) offered an anesthetic. - Shu

Posts.Title: Biopsy Scheduled - Just a few questions

Posts.Content: wbigs - Had left inguinal hernia repaired at age 5, right side at age 18. Both sides laproscopic repair w/ patches at age 58 (I think dropping 8 feet out of a tree I was trimming, and landing flat on my feet was what did it). After the bilateral laproscopic repairs, lengthy sitting caused pains in the groin area. Gradually got better over two years. Still, every six months or so I'd do something that felt like things had broken loose. Indeed, about three weeks before the prostatectomy I was cleaning up a confined space, lifted a chunk of concrete rubble and twisted upper body to side. Fortunately, as on previous occasions, a week or two avoiding such exertions firmed the area up again. At pre-surgery consults I had asked the Doc about prior hernias. He said that did not normally rule out surgery as a prostate cancer treatment, and that robotic was better than open. Doc had several thousand operations; his usual schedule was "three on Monday, three on Thursday). In the short term, first six months, recovery from the prostatectomy was easier than from the earlier bilateral repair. Long term, three years out from surgery, the groin area is less tolerant of abuse from prolonged sitting or heavy lifting. I guess at 72 y.o. maybe it's time to cut back a little. My avatar, spike of a flowering agave plant in our front yard, was chosen as a tribute to the nerve sparing surgery of Dr. John Davis at MD Anderson. The oak tree in the background was taken down mostly without assistance two years after the prostatectomy. WBigs, you should give strict adherence to the lifting restrictions post surgery. Just sayin',,, Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: 12 days post-robotic prostatectomy, AND DOING GREAT!

Posts.Content: You say the incision hurts. My experience (bilateral hernia repair about 2000, prostatectomy last year) is ..some sharp 'pinching' type pains at random times. Staples touching nerves, I think. Eventually builds surrounding tissue to isolate, and the problem goes away ..'dead' pain in groin or upper leg area. Don't be sitting for more than 30 minutes at a time. Walk around a bit and get the circulation going. A lot of swelling in that area, and sitting folded up is just not good for letting fluids flow around and through. That will be mostly over after 6 months, but not completely go away till about two years. Hard to do if your job is driving a truck, but there it is. Best wishes to you - Shu

Posts.Title: incision pain

Posts.Content: Re. extended orgasms: I suspect there are hormone changes with prostate removal that edge us more to the female side, but with the prostatectomy just short of age 70 its hard to separate that causality from ordinary aging. I did find that, getting older, sex was becoming more tantric - less wham-bang ejaculations; more process and body awareness. It does raise awareness of the male pelvic floor muscles - a good thing when that is all we have left to depend on for urinary continance. Congrats on the "<0.1". My Doc said PSA every six months for five years, then it was up to me if I wanted to continue. Best wishes. - Shu

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer t3b gleason 9

Posts.Content: Yep, what they said. ..every PC case is different ..Gleason 3+3 there is no crashing need for immediate treatment. ..Prostate cancers grow slowly, but grow they do. ..Biopsy is a crap-shoot as to where the cores are sampled from (could miss finding the big one); MRI gives you added perspective about what's going on inside. ..generally ....affects of surgery are immediate; a few weeks of down time, continence and sexual function (given that nerves were spared) recover slowly ....affects of radiation treatments are slow or delayed; continence and sexual function problems may appear some years out. ..as we get older: ....whatever cancer is there continues to grow, usually slowly; ....our bodies generally get less tolerant of medical interventions (surgery, radiation, whatever) ....we can continue life as normal, avoiding/delaying immediate and/or lingering affects from treatment till a more convenient time ....available treatment options become more refined and improved ..but, until you select and start a treatment, you've got this decision hanging fire occupying your mind Main thing is, keep on top of it with regular examinations and blood tests; if you go with Active Surveilance, set some trigger points for Active Treatment intervention. Best wishes to you - shu

Posts.Title: PSA Results all good

Posts.Content: For me, about 4 hours in surgery; 2 nights in hospital. Am thinking three hours and one night are closer to the average. I had previous hernia patches the Docs had to work around or break loose, and was just short of 70 yrs old at the time. Other folks in the cohort were walking around more easily than I after the first overnight, but I didn't feel ready till after a full day of rest. Early the second morning I swapped out the catheter bed bag for the leg bag, threw on some PJ bottoms and a robe, scrounged up an empty IV tree for support, and slouched down to the Starbucks at the main cafeteria with Wife. I was ready to get released. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Day 22 - having passed the "Don't lift anything heavier than 5/10/15 lb." (depending on source being quoted) mark. GENERAL PROGRESS: good. Actually some regression or lack of progress in the past week, due to pushing the activity level. Most problems in the area of groin/scrotum drainage (see section below). On Day 14 I wrestled the dead battery out of the riding lawn mower, and wrestled the new one in. On Day 20 I mowed some of the lawn, did some bush trimming with chain saw, and pried some large weeds out of the North Pasture. That was too much. Making effort now to stay horizontal more of the day, cycle more water during the day, fight temptation to get on the tractor and do some dirt work. PAIN: no problem. Left off the Rx narcotic pain pills after Week 1 and the 300 mile ride home from Houston. Extra strength Tylenol for another week, then nothing. Surface wounds healing nicely. "Super glue" mostly peeled off. Three of the six incision sites have a small absorbable-thread suture. BLADDER CONTROL: somewhere between "good as can be expected" and "astonishing." Peed during sleep on two of the first four nights after the urinary catheter came out (day 10). No problems since then. Keep a precautionary absorbent/impermeable pad on the bed. Left off any absorbent pad in the shorts last night, to allow for better scrotal mobility and drainage. Watch fluid intake two hours before bed time. Some nights awake to pee at two hour intervals (vice 3.5) which may interfere with getting into full REM sleep state. Daytime, excepting a small ocassional dribble or squirt, I pee or hold as usual. Pre-operative, had ocassional intense urge to urinate with only partially filled bladder. Believe this is a pinched nerve issue, related to squashed discs in lower spine. No change here. Volume flow rate, which had begun to decrease "noticeably" (but not "troublingly") pre-operative, is increased. There is a "burning" sensation (hardly dignifiable by the label "pain") during urination, which seems to be at the suture site of bladder neck and urethra. ERECTILE FUNCTION: good as can be expected. This was not a problem pre-operative. Twenty-one days is also the marker for starting some manual stimulation - and another area I'll admit to pushing the prescribed/recommended schedule. Nothing approaching a genuine boner, but about what you'd expect for having an inch or so cut out of your urethra. BOWEL FUNCTION AND RECTAL: a lot of tenderness, hemroids. I've never been attentive to proper hydration or regular bowel movements. Post-operative I've kept with the ducosate sodium stool softener (had never before used these, nor any laxatives). Hydration, not so much. Bowel movements have been generally regular and without much straining. Eating has been heavy, particularly the first week post-operative. I think the antibiotic enema on the day pre-operative killed off much of the beneficial digestive gut fauna. There is much tenderness in the area, and some fluid leaking. I suspect the Surgeons stuck various wands in there to position organs for the robot fingers. GROIN/SCROTUM: the most bothersome area. Much of the groin swelling and scrotal drainage problem can likely be laid to the bi-lateral inguinal hernia repair meshes of ten years ago. About every two years since I've done something to over-stress the area, required a week or two to firm up again. Surgeon's notes indicate work-around of these patches added 30 minutes to his normal time for the operation. Meanwhile, I'm walking slow and slightly bow-legged; making a point to stay horizontal when possible for good drainage.

Posts.Title: Day 22, post-operative robotic prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Agreed, the Gleason 8 and a palpable nodule point to selecting and getting on with a path of treatment without undue delay. Yet panic at this point is both unhelpful and uncalled for. Only 2 of 13 cores in the biopsy showing cancerous is good to hear. Likewise there seems to be no suggestion yet of metastasis. Plenty of folks have recovered from far worse. A few weeks to study the options, any additional tests, and make a decision for action; then schedule the the selected treatment. A small number of months between initial diagnosis and start of treatment seems to be typical. After reviewing the options, and if further tests suggest no spread beyond the prostate, and your Dad is otherwise in generally good health, he may opt for removal of the prostate. This would leave available options for radiation or other treatments if some cancer cells had remained behind. While perhaps startling to contemplate at first - to remove the prostate the urethra is cut at entrance and exit of the gland, exterior nerves and other tissue carefully peeled away, and the lower urethra stitched back to the base of the bladder - the procedure is quite commonly done. Both 'open' (hands on) and 'robotic' (remote controlled mechanical arms through small incisions) are done. Look for a surgeon with several hundred operations experience. This might be at a major university teaching hospital. My surgeon had perhaps over two thousand operations; his normal week was three on Monday, three on Thursday. And, yes, if you would mention your father's age, any other important medical problems, and some PSA readings, it would help align our comments more closely to your Dad's circumstances. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Back from RALRP

Posts.Content: Stay hydrated. Keep on schedule with stool softener pills. It'll get there eventually, and you'll feel a lot better. (Stop me if I've told this story before.) I had not given much study on what to eat, and post-op just tried to refill the gut with soft, fiber and roughage rich fare. Operation day was Monday. We were in the Rotary House hotel there on the MD Anderson campus. By Thursday evening I had got all the gas out but was beginning to feel righteous well packed up from the food. About 2:00AM Friday I woke up Wife, we hopped in the car and went driving around looking for a more serious laxative. You would think there would be an all-night pharmacy in Houston close to the Texas Medical Center, but none that we found. Not on Holcomb Blvd., not on Main St. Found a stop-n-rob on Main that was at least open, locked up and selling stuff through a slot under a bullet proof glass window, but nothing in the laxative dept. to offer. So, back to the hotel. The venture did involve a fair amount of walking, and maybe that exercise and turning the gut did the trick. Immediately hit the throne room and was magnanimously rewarded. After that, as they say, the rest was easy. Wishing you an equally glorious outcome. - Shu

Posts.Content: There is a saying: "Eat a live frog first thing every morning. After that, the rest of the day will be easy." The worst part is the total bowel purge stuff they give you to drink for the pre-op. Hang loose, my friend. It'll be over before you know it. - Shu.

Posts.Content: Montrob - Sorry for your condition. You did not mention the Gleason score from biopsy, other tests and results pre-surgery that might indicate stage of the cancer, nor pathology results of the removed tissues. On the other thing, there can be life without sex - but sex without life, not so much.

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Hi ChiliDog. Welcome to the forum I feel qualified to speak on this, being about the same age as your Hubby - at least as to the surgery. Enervating effects of radiation or drug treatments, I have no experience. I say no reason to jump the gun quitting work. In about year 2000 I had abdominal surgery - laproscopic hernia repair, both sides. Prostatectomy was August, 2013. Following both surgeries it took a month or so to return to most normal activities not involving feats of strength. For about a year following, it was painful to stay seated for more than a half hour at a time. This may not be the case for normal prostatectomy, but for me where hernia areas were involved, it was. The solution in 2000 was to get a chair that sets in a kneeling type posture. This time I just got some spare 2x4s and plywood, and slapped together a U shaped riser to make a 'stand-up' desk. Added benefit, the computer now fits on the floor under the desk, the back-up power supply and wiring is out of view behind the riser. Also, bought a drawing table stool to sit on. As for the rest of it, about three months ago I took down and chainsawed into firewood the 2 foot diameter oak tree in my avatar picture. Tell Hubby to keep at it as long as he wants. - shu

Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Yeah, biopsy is a bummer. Pissing and ejaculating blood for a week or so. If yr man still is not mostly recovered after two weeks, I'd think that's not normal, but I'm not the guy to suggest what to do about it. First biopsy I had - about 2000 - was un-sedated an not pleasant in any way. For the biopsy in 2013 the Urologist (different Doc) suggested an anesthesiologist. I said "Fine. Do what you need to do, but I don't want to know about it while it's happening." Looks like yr hubby - given age, Gleason score, family history, general health - is about the same relative position as I was. Rational case could be made for just watching and waiting, but I and wife instantly went for prostate removal. Best wishes - shu
