Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Yeah, biopsy is a bummer. Pissing and ejaculating blood for a week or so. If yr man still is not mostly recovered after two weeks, I'd think that's not normal, but I'm not the guy to suggest what to do about it. First biopsy I had - about 2000 - was un-sedated an not pleasant in any way. For the biopsy in 2013 the Urologist (different Doc) suggested an anesthesiologist. I said "Fine. Do what you need to do, but I don't want to know about it while it's happening." Looks like yr hubby - given age, Gleason score, family history, general health - is about the same relative position as I was. Rational case could be made for just watching and waiting, but I and wife instantly went for prostate removal. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Hello Kens - Pretty much what everyone else said. At Gleason 3+3=6 there is probably no huge rush for treatment - keeping in mind you never know what the random biopsy cores missed. At age 57 you may be wanting to get more mileage out of your prostate than I did at close to 70. That might skew the decision toward radiation if/when active treatment is needed. Sex after surgery is still good, just a lot less messy. Gives new meaning to the phrase "dry humping." But, yeah - I think most of the guys on the board here go for the surgery first. Done early, before the horse gets out of the barn and into the lymph nodes etc., by an experienced operating team, prospects for post surgery bladder control and erectile function are good. If the pathology report on the prostate shows containment, and the PSA is undetectable (<0.1) at the 6 week check, chances are very good you are clear of the cancer. But do let us know what you decide, and give us some progress checks. It's a good crew here, willing to share their stories. - shu

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Well, I've never asked the Doc.s about it, but I'd assumed it'd be like flying. You might have a pilot, co-pilot, instructor pilot, and flight examiner - all doing their assigned duties and logging time on the same flight. You might have a daVinci trainee getting 'stick time' on the rough cutting, and the team chief/master surgeon/instructor doing the more critical parts. Both get to chalk up one mission. B'lieve I saw somewhere there are three 'hands' and two operator consoles on the machine. Could be mistaken, tho. -shu

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Mimi - Can't speak with authority to your question of why the low PSA. With family members in both paternal and maternal lines having/had PC, I started testing early. I was surprised, but compliant, when the urologist wanted a biopsy at PSA 4.0. Glad that he did. I'd say yr husband's biopsy results are what they are. If you believe them, and have selected surgery, then focus on getting ready for that. After that, settle back and wait on the pathology report - which will be released whenever it is ready. Examining the whole prostate and other removed material, along with the 6 week post-op PSA test will give a high confidence level report on whether/or not the cancer was entirely removed. Unfortunately, the operation is not reversible. It'd be nice if we could clean up the prostate and put it back in place like the carburetor on an engine. BTW, I noticed several folks posting the size of their prostate from the path. report, so I went back and looked up my own. Comparatively rather small. Perhaps that is a factor in low PSA reading vs. Gleason score. Best wishes, - shu

Posts.Title: Surgery in 2 days

Posts.Content: What they said, mostly. As to pain post operative, you will likely be prescribed some heavy duty pain killer pills on release from the hospital. I took one or two, but found Advil was all that was needed. Most of us here, I think, were the same. Actual pain from the surgical wounds is not a worry. The CO2 gas needed to create the operating cavity was, for me, no problem at all - just a lot of farting. Shoulder pain from the position we are placed on the operating table, likewise was not an issue for me. The catheter can trigger sudden and intense bladder spasms, but keep the tip of the penis lubricated and should be no problem. After you start walking, the catheter is mostly must an annoyance to drag the bag around around and empty it, and an occasional distracting tug on your Johnson. Catheter removal is a non-issue. Slips right out like taking a whizz. First bowel movement is a major event. But about day 3 or 4 when you really start worrying, it'll all work out. Just watch what you eat - soft foods, soft fiber, stool softeners on schedule. A lot of discomforts, but not much real pain. By about day 3 you'll have figured out how to move around. After that, the problem is mostly to hold yourself back from trying too much too soon. There is a lot more healing needs to take place inside than the few surface cuts indicate. Rest and relax Monday, do the bowel purge stuff and fasting, you'll do fine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: recooping after surgery

Posts.Content: Bill - Here is the tail of a thread (still active about mid-way down the board now). http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...-with-PC/page5 I'd brought a bathrobe and some PJ bottoms presentable enough for outside wear. During our "free weekend" Wife found some cheap hospital scrub bottoms at the market down the road. You'll probably want to stay at least a couple of days Houston after the operation. First poop makes ya' feel a lot more human. FWIW, our magueys were going into efflorescence about that time. My avatar pic. at left is a tribute to Dr. Davis' "nerve-sparing" procedure. Welcome to the forum, and best wishes for next week. - Shu

Posts.Title: prostatectomy - MD Anderson on July 27th

Posts.Content: Hey, Bow - Prostatectomy is serious surgery, but also *very* commonly done. A good team will have done many procecures, seen and handled just about every problem likely to come up. There is really not a lot of pain involved. Likely you will get some high power pain meds on leaving the hospital, but most of us seems to just get on with over-the-counter stuff after the first day. The catheter is mostly a non-issue. Yeah, you will have a bag strapped to your ankle for a week or so. Keep the tip of the urethra clean and lubed. Don't push too hard getting back to normal duty - there is a lot more healing needs be done inside compared to the few cuts on the surface. Give it a couple of months. Do keep up with simple walking - gets blood flowing through the area and keeps gentle stretching during healing. Urinary control and erections vary widely with individuals. We lose the urinary sphincter at the prostate, and so are left with just the pelvic floor sphincter - the same equipment as the ladies have for urinary control. If tumors are not piercing the prostate shell, a good surgery team should leave the erectile nerves with minimal trauma. If not, and erections are important, there are other means. Having got the cancer out is a major mental comfort. Best wishes for you - Shu

Posts.Title: Want the real expectation for Prostate removal

Posts.Content: Caddy - Agreed, 3+3 is nothing to panic over. Of course that is just what they happened to strike with the needle. No telling what else may be in there unless you take the whole gland out for a look. 5/12 of the sample showing positive for cancer would, I think, disqualify you for just Active Surveillance. If so, best to select a treatment plan and move ahead with it. ASAdvocate, who jumped in above, keeps current on when Active Surveillance is/not appropriate. I was 69.5 y.o. at diagnosis. Father, Uncle, and Brother went for radiation treatment (in one form or another). I decided on surgical removal. If you are in good health and physical condition, surgery should not be a problem. Be not hesitant to do some surgeon shopping. No reason to feel restricted to guy who diagnosed you. We got a self-referral to MD Anderson. Whatever, if you decide on surgery, look for someone who has done a bunch and is currently still doing a bunch. Our surgeon at MDA had logged well into the thousands. Hope this helps. Best wishes to you. - Shu

Posts.Content: If you see Dr. John Davis, surgeon in the Genitourinary Cancer Dept., pls give him my regards. My avatar - our agave plant going into inflorescence - is in honor of his "nerve sparing" technique. Very best wishes to you and Hubby. - shu
Posts.Title: Decision made to go with MD Anderson instead of Urologist who diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Oh, BTW you mentioned frequent need to urinate. If you search the forum you'll find a post wherein I discuss a problem with sudden compelling need to pee, beginning about age 40. Actual cause, I believe, was pressure on nerves due to compressed discs in lower spine. Yoga was a big help in relieving this. - shu

Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Mario - Take ten slow deep breaths and relax. The usual way to determine if cancer is actually present is with a biopsy - taking some random core samples by way of a spring-fired needle mounted on an ultrasound head - the whole affair inserted through the anus. This procedure is not enjoyable in any way, but is endurable, and is done locally in the urologist's office. Something to keep in mind, the biopsy is *just* a random sampling. Usually if cancer is there the biopsy will rake in some of it, but since it is just a sampling it will not give a full and complete picture. So - if you are a worrier - there you are. It's what we have to deal with. The good news: 1) prostate cancers usually grow slowly, so panic is not called for here; 2) a PSA of 2 with an intact prostate is like nothing (I am not a medical professional, but that is my take on it); and 3) re-read point #1. If the urologist says not to worry, I'd be inclined to believe him/her. But to settle your mind you could always gather up the lab reports and run them by another urologist for a second opinion. Best wishes, -shu

Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: Tim - My first post-op bowel movement - blessed and most welcome event - was at D+3.5. I don't recall any particular dietary restrictions; was two nights in the hospital, and there were no restrictions on meal menus. Out of the hospital, my plan was to get the gut restocked. I went for soft roughage - pinto beans, salad greens, soft vegetables - and plenty of fluids to avoid the system having to draw moisture from the intestines. At three and a half days the gut commenced rumbling. This was 0200 hrs in the AM. We drove around for an hour looking for an all night pharmacy or someplace to score some laxatives. No joy. Back to the hotel. Within a half hour I was on the throne gettin it done. After that it was all normal-normal gastro-intestinal wise. Hope this helps. Best wishes. Shu

Posts.Title: I guess it's my turn

Posts.Content: Yep, what they said. ..every PC case is different ..Gleason 3+3 there is no crashing need for immediate treatment. ..Prostate cancers grow slowly, but grow they do. ..Biopsy is a crap-shoot as to where the cores are sampled from (could miss finding the big one); MRI gives you added perspective about what's going on inside. ..generally ....affects of surgery are immediate; a few weeks of down time, continence and sexual function (given that nerves were spared) recover slowly ....affects of radiation treatments are slow or delayed; continence and sexual function problems may appear some years out. ..as we get older: ....whatever cancer is there continues to grow, usually slowly; ....our bodies generally get less tolerant of medical interventions (surgery, radiation, whatever) ....we can continue life as normal, avoiding/delaying immediate and/or lingering affects from treatment till a more convenient time ....available treatment options become more refined and improved ..but, until you select and start a treatment, you've got this decision hanging fire occupying your mind Main thing is, keep on top of it with regular examinations and blood tests; if you go with Active Surveilance, set some trigger points for Active Treatment intervention. Best wishes to you - shu

Posts.Title: I guess it's my turn

Posts.Content: Hi McNova - I'm thinking most here would agree at Gleason 6 that active surveillance is a reasonable choice - keeping in mind of course that the biopsy is just a random sample, there could be something more nefarious lurking undetected. Most here would agree, I think, that Gleason 7 (particularly if it's 4+3=7 rather than 3+4=7), at age 67 if your Dad is in generally good health, it's time to select and move forward with some treatment method. For us, at age 69 1/2, receiving the news of the biopsy cold, we went from zero to decision for surgery in probably less than 5 minutes. Among other considerations I wanted to get it done before I got any older, and before the Afraudable Care Act created more spread between Health Insurance and actual Health Care. Prostatectomy, either 'hands-in' or 'robotic' is actually a rather routine procedure. Best done sooner than later, before any tumor(s) gets away from the site. Yes, there is a percentage for incontinence or sexual function problems; We were in otherwise good health, just on the opposite side of the cusp from your Dad's Gleason 6, and were ready to accept the percentages. There is, of course, the alternative of radiation treatment. The decision of what, if any, treatment is of course your Father's. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Dad recently diagnosed :(

Posts.Content: What they said, mostly. As to pain post operative, you will likely be prescribed some heavy duty pain killer pills on release from the hospital. I took one or two, but found Advil was all that was needed. Most of us here, I think, were the same. Actual pain from the surgical wounds is not a worry. The CO2 gas needed to create the operating cavity was, for me, no problem at all - just a lot of farting. Shoulder pain from the position we are placed on the operating table, likewise was not an issue for me. The catheter can trigger sudden and intense bladder spasms, but keep the tip of the penis lubricated and should be no problem. After you start walking, the catheter is mostly must an annoyance to drag the bag around around and empty it, and an occasional distracting tug on your Johnson. Catheter removal is a non-issue. Slips right out like taking a whizz. First bowel movement is a major event. But about day 3 or 4 when you really start worrying, it'll all work out. Just watch what you eat - soft foods, soft fiber, stool softeners on schedule. A lot of discomforts, but not much real pain. By about day 3 you'll have figured out how to move around. After that, the problem is mostly to hold yourself back from trying too much too soon. There is a lot more healing needs to take place inside than the few surface cuts indicate. Rest and relax Monday, do the bowel purge stuff and fasting, you'll do fine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Content: Sounds like you're getting a handle on it, DogD. Ease off the liquid intake as bed-time approaches, as others have said. Coffee, tea, alcohol, etc. with caution and temperance. There will, of course, be less pressure and drip when you are supine than when vertical; but if you were not dripping or flowing as you walked from bed to toilet in yr post above, then it seems yr bod has the right idea about holding and release. Just give it time to learn and adapt. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: For me, about 4 hours in surgery; 2 nights in hospital. Am thinking three hours and one night are closer to the average. I had previous hernia patches the Docs had to work around or break loose, and was just short of 70 yrs old at the time. Other folks in the cohort were walking around more easily than I after the first overnight, but I didn't feel ready till after a full day of rest. Early the second morning I swapped out the catheter bed bag for the leg bag, threw on some PJ bottoms and a robe, scrounged up an empty IV tree for support, and slouched down to the Starbucks at the main cafeteria with Wife. I was ready to get released. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: How long is the actual surgery?

Posts.Content: Agreed, the Gleason 8 and a palpable nodule point to selecting and getting on with a path of treatment without undue delay. Yet panic at this point is both unhelpful and uncalled for. Only 2 of 13 cores in the biopsy showing cancerous is good to hear. Likewise there seems to be no suggestion yet of metastasis. Plenty of folks have recovered from far worse. A few weeks to study the options, any additional tests, and make a decision for action; then schedule the the selected treatment. A small number of months between initial diagnosis and start of treatment seems to be typical. After reviewing the options, and if further tests suggest no spread beyond the prostate, and your Dad is otherwise in generally good health, he may opt for removal of the prostate. This would leave available options for radiation or other treatments if some cancer cells had remained behind. While perhaps startling to contemplate at first - to remove the prostate the urethra is cut at entrance and exit of the gland, exterior nerves and other tissue carefully peeled away, and the lower urethra stitched back to the base of the bladder - the procedure is quite commonly done. Both 'open' (hands on) and 'robotic' (remote controlled mechanical arms through small incisions) are done. Look for a surgeon with several hundred operations experience. This might be at a major university teaching hospital. My surgeon had perhaps over two thousand operations; his normal week was three on Monday, three on Thursday. And, yes, if you would mention your father's age, any other important medical problems, and some PSA readings, it would help align our comments more closely to your Dad's circumstances. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Frency - Let your body be your guide, and don't push it too hard. After a double laproscopic hernia repair about 2000, it was a great while before I could sit for longer than 30 minutes without developing pains in the creases of the groin. It was about two years post surgery until "like it never happened" - except for some groin pain for a few days after heavy or twisting lifting. Recovery after the DaVinci RP was easier than the hernia repairs - generally "like it never happened" after one year post surgery. Yet there are still groin pains after an hour of computer sitting. My exercise of choice was the Concept2 air-drag rower (groin compressions deeper than cycling). I never could get back up to my pre-daVinci workout lengths of 10K meters. After two years, gave up and got Concept2's stand-up SkiErg. I'm back on the rower some now - can tolerate 2-3K meters daily. Best wishes - Shu And, yes, in the month or so between preliminary appointment at MD Anderson and the daVinci gig, I kicked up the workouts a bit - both to stay busy, displace worry, and to trim a few pounds to give the Docs a cleaner deck.

Posts.Title: Vigorous Exercise Post RP

Posts.Content: There is a saying: "Eat a live frog first thing every morning. After that, the rest of the day will be easy." The worst part is the total bowel purge stuff they give you to drink for the pre-op. Hang loose, my friend. It'll be over before you know it. - Shu.

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Tough call, Fred. For me, a few years younger, higher biopsy Gleason score but low enough to strongly suggest containment, small prostate, it was an instant decision to seek surgery at MDA. At 74 with but 1 core at G:3+3=6, some fallback treatments available if needed and more likely to appear as the future unfolds, an established patient number at MDA - active surveillance seems a quite reasonable path to take. You did not mention a trajectory of past PSA readings, PSA doubling time (if any), etc. Best wishes however you proceed. - Shu

Posts.Title: Gleason 6, Should I press for surgery?

Posts.Content: Stay hydrated. Keep on schedule with stool softener pills. It'll get there eventually, and you'll feel a lot better. (Stop me if I've told this story before.) I had not given much study on what to eat, and post-op just tried to refill the gut with soft, fiber and roughage rich fare. Operation day was Monday. We were in the Rotary House hotel there on the MD Anderson campus. By Thursday evening I had got all the gas out but was beginning to feel righteous well packed up from the food. About 2:00AM Friday I woke up Wife, we hopped in the car and went driving around looking for a more serious laxative. You would think there would be an all-night pharmacy in Houston close to the Texas Medical Center, but none that we found. Not on Holcomb Blvd., not on Main St. Found a stop-n-rob on Main that was at least open, locked up and selling stuff through a slot under a bullet proof glass window, but nothing in the laxative dept. to offer. So, back to the hotel. The venture did involve a fair amount of walking, and maybe that exercise and turning the gut did the trick. Immediately hit the throne room and was magnanimously rewarded. After that, as they say, the rest was easy. Wishing you an equally glorious outcome. - Shu

Posts.Title: Back from RALRP

Posts.Content: Hi ChiliDog. Welcome to the forum I feel qualified to speak on this, being about the same age as your Hubby - at least as to the surgery. Enervating effects of radiation or drug treatments, I have no experience. I say no reason to jump the gun quitting work. In about year 2000 I had abdominal surgery - laproscopic hernia repair, both sides. Prostatectomy was August, 2013. Following both surgeries it took a month or so to return to most normal activities not involving feats of strength. For about a year following, it was painful to stay seated for more than a half hour at a time. This may not be the case for normal prostatectomy, but for me where hernia areas were involved, it was. The solution in 2000 was to get a chair that sets in a kneeling type posture. This time I just got some spare 2x4s and plywood, and slapped together a U shaped riser to make a 'stand-up' desk. Added benefit, the computer now fits on the floor under the desk, the back-up power supply and wiring is out of view behind the riser. Also, bought a drawing table stool to sit on. As for the rest of it, about three months ago I took down and chainsawed into firewood the 2 foot diameter oak tree in my avatar picture. Tell Hubby to keep at it as long as he wants. - shu

Posts.Title: meet my team at MD Anderson elected RALPH July 28th

Posts.Content: Ron - A warm welcome, and thank you for sharing. The dissonance between rather stable PSA 4.1 and biopsy G:7 with the pathology result are surprising - illustrating that the biopsy is just a random sample, and that all PC cases are different. The 8 of 12 cores positive maybe were a pointer to larger involvement. Yes, good call to have done the surgery and cleared out the bulk of the bad stuff. All together, confirms why we "instantly" selected surgery when we were presented with the biopsy news. Pathology of the removed prostate provides the best information about the cancer. Radiation can be used after prostatectomy to punch back any residual cancer; surgery after radiation as the primary treatment, not so much. You indicate (at 09:30 post above) that DRE was done, prostate was enlarged. But no nodules or deformation felt?? Thank you again for sharing your information; very helpful to guys coming into the Board. And very, very best wishes to you in treatment! - Shu

Posts.Title: New to the Forum

Posts.Content: Just my opinion, Izzic, but I don't think it is a common problem, and should in any event be manageable. Same as a baby: change the pad when wet, clean and dry the area, apply powder or oil on the skin. I'd not let that worry affect your treatment decision. If you are in good physical condition, do kegel exercises to shape-up the pelvic floor muscles, and no unusual problems with the surgery, you may just have minor leakage and only for a few weeks. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Vigorous Exercise Post RP

Posts.Content: Hello Deech, and welcome aboard. My *non-professional* opinion agrees with yr Hubby's Urologist, and with Highlander. A clear trend of PSA readings, even suggesting maybe more than G:3+3=6 present. That is within the window of Actionable but likely fully curable. Also, I'm thinking that no amount of antibiotics are gonna shrink whatever is in there; it will only -albeit and however slowly - get larger. Sixty-Eight is still young. if there are no other health problems. So maybe an appropriate question for Hubby is: "You do not now want to select and start on a course of treatment because ... ?" Wife and I, at age 69, "instantly" went for the daVinci prostatectomy. The whole gland goes to the pathology lab for analysis; an immediate drop of PSA to undetectable points to none of the cancer having escaped or been left behind. In the hands of an experienced surgical team, prospects for urinary continence and erectile function (if that is important) are quite good - the better the earlier the surgery is done. There are several radiation treatments available, with equivalent cure rates, which others here have taken with good result. We went for the surgery not because of any tinfoil-hat radiophobia, but rather for the above cited reasons. My best wishes to you both. - shu

Posts.Content: Hello Deech, and welcome aboard. My *non-professional* opinion agrees with yr Hubby's Urologist, and with Highlander. A clear trend of PSA readings, even suggesting maybe more than G:3+3=6 present. That is within the window of Actionable but likely fully curable. Also, I'm thinking that no amount of antibiotics are gonna shrink whatever is in there; it will only -albeit and however slowly - get larger. Sixty-Eight is still young. if there are no other health problems. So maybe an appropriate question for Hubby is: "You do not now want to select and start on a course of treatment because ... ?" Posts.Title: Antibiotics and Second Opinion before Surgery

Posts.Content: Agreed, the Gleason 8 and a palpable nodule point to selecting and getting on with a path of treatment without undue delay. Yet panic at this point is both unhelpful and uncalled for. Only 2 of 13 cores in the biopsy showing cancerous is good to hear. Likewise there seems to be no suggestion yet of metastasis. Plenty of folks have recovered from far worse. A few weeks to study the options, any additional tests, and make a decision for action; then schedule the the selected treatment. A small number of months between initial diagnosis and start of treatment seems to be typical. After reviewing the options, and if further tests suggest no spread beyond the prostate, and your Dad is otherwise in generally good health, he may opt for removal of the prostate. This would leave available options for radiation or other treatments if some cancer cells had remained behind. While perhaps startling to contemplate at first - to remove the prostate the urethra is cut at entrance and exit of the gland, exterior nerves and other tissue carefully peeled away, and the lower urethra stitched back to the base of the bladder - the procedure is quite commonly done. Both 'open' (hands on) and 'robotic' (remote controlled mechanical arms through small incisions) are done. Look for a surgeon with several hundred operations experience. This might be at a major university teaching hospital. My surgeon had perhaps over two thousand operations; his normal week was three on Monday, three on Thursday. And, yes, if you would mention your father's age, any other important medical problems, and some PSA readings, it would help align our comments more closely to your Dad's circumstances. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: What's the normal PSA testing schedule following surgery?

Posts.Content: Good to hear. First poop is a major event. Keep him hydrated. Stewed prunes, prune juice, fresh dates may help get things moving. It is serious surgery, so mind the instructions about lifting. Keep him walking. Best wishes for a happy pathology report - Shu P.S. About six months after my RP, Family Medicine Doc's office called. They wanted to schedule an appointment for vitamin D counseling; "Doctor says it's important for prostate health." I told them I'd be happy to show up for the counseling, but I couldn't bring my prostate 'cause I'd left that in Houston.

Posts.Title: The Prostate has left the building.

Posts.Content: Sincere condolences on your loss, Ampersand. Others may correct me, as I may be wrong on this. Hormone therapy can suppress prostate activity - thus reduce the rate of prostate cancer growth. Hormone therapy will neither remove the cancer nor kill it in place - thus it cannot be a true "cure." Moreover, messing with hormones can bring unwelcome physical and psychological effects - hot flashes, reduced sexual libido, etc. Relevant questions are: what courses of treatment were offered to your Father; what course did he select; and did he follow the course he selected. The choice of treatment, and holding to it, are the patient's responsibility. That information may be in existence but, because of passage of time and privacy considerations, difficult for you to obtain. You might begin by seeking out a friend or relative with whom your Father may have confided about his treatments. Also, if you have not, you would see what information is available on the death certificate. Again, most sincere sympathy for your loss. & yes, age 65 is too early. - Shu

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer death

Posts.Content: Hello Kens - Pretty much what everyone else said. At Gleason 3+3=6 there is probably no huge rush for treatment - keeping in mind you never know what the random biopsy cores missed. At age 57 you may be wanting to get more mileage out of your prostate than I did at close to 70. That might skew the decision toward radiation if/when active treatment is needed. Sex after surgery is still good, just a lot less messy. Gives new meaning to the phrase "dry humping." But, yeah - I think most of the guys on the board here go for the surgery first. Done early, before the horse gets out of the barn and into the lymph nodes etc., by an experienced operating team, prospects for post surgery bladder control and erectile function are good. If the pathology report on the prostate shows containment, and the PSA is undetectable (<0.1) at the 6 week check, chances are very good you are clear of the cancer. But do let us know what you decide, and give us some progress checks. It's a good crew here, willing to share their stories. - shu

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Hi ChiliDog. Welcome to the forum I feel qualified to speak on this, being about the same age as your Hubby - at least as to the surgery. Enervating effects of radiation or drug treatments, I have no experience. I say no reason to jump the gun quitting work. In about year 2000 I had abdominal surgery - laproscopic hernia repair, both sides. Prostatectomy was August, 2013. Following both surgeries it took a month or so to return to most normal activities not involving feats of strength. For about a year following, it was painful to stay seated for more than a half hour at a time. This may not be the case for normal prostatectomy, but for me where hernia areas were involved, it was. The solution in 2000 was to get a chair that sets in a kneeling type posture. This time I just got some spare 2x4s and plywood, and slapped together a U shaped riser to make a 'stand-up' desk. Added benefit, the computer now fits on the floor under the desk, the back-up power supply and wiring is out of view behind the riser. Also, bought a drawing table stool to sit on. As for the rest of it, about three months ago I took down and chainsawed into firewood the 2 foot diameter oak tree in my avatar picture. Tell Hubby to keep at it as long as he wants. - shu

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Hey, Prato - I've been away a long time too, but is not the standard <0.1? My understanding was the test equipment may register some number less than 0.1 mg/nl, but anything that low is within the jiggle tolerance of the equipment and is therefore not really differentiable from zero. It is, within the capability limits of the equipment, "not detectable." Alla you numbers is below that. Nicht var? - shu

Posts.Content: Tell the surgeon about it. My guess, won't make any difference. They'll probably just slap a patch on it before they close you. Fix ya' right up. (I'm good in the belly-button dept., but had past inguinal hernia repairs and maybe some new breaches. Slowed the team down some, but didn't stop them.) Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Herniated navel complications during surgery

Posts.Content: Sincere condolences on your loss, Ampersand. Others may correct me, as I may be wrong on this. Hormone therapy can suppress prostate activity - thus reduce the rate of prostate cancer growth. Hormone therapy will neither remove the cancer nor kill it in place - thus it cannot be a true "cure." Moreover, messing with hormones can bring unwelcome physical and psychological effects - hot flashes, reduced sexual libido, etc. Relevant questions are: what courses of treatment were offered to your Father; what course did he select; and did he follow the course he selected. The choice of treatment, and holding to it, are the patient's responsibility. That information may be in existence but, because of passage of time and privacy considerations, difficult for you to obtain. You might begin by seeking out a friend or relative with whom your Father may have confided about his treatments. Also, if you have not, you would see what information is available on the death certificate. Again, most sincere sympathy for your loss. & yes, age 65 is too early. - Shu

Posts.Title: Back from RALRP

Posts.Content: Stay hydrated. Keep on schedule with stool softener pills. It'll get there eventually, and you'll feel a lot better. (Stop me if I've told this story before.) I had not given much study on what to eat, and post-op just tried to refill the gut with soft, fiber and roughage rich fare. Operation day was Monday. We were in the Rotary House hotel there on the MD Anderson campus. By Thursday evening I had got all the gas out but was beginning to feel righteous well packed up from the food. About 2:00AM Friday I woke up Wife, we hopped in the car and went driving around looking for a more serious laxative. You would think there would be an all-night pharmacy in Houston close to the Texas Medical Center, but none that we found. Not on Holcomb Blvd., not on Main St. Found a stop-n-rob on Main that was at least open, locked up and selling stuff through a slot under a bullet proof glass window, but nothing in the laxative dept. to offer. So, back to the hotel. The venture did involve a fair amount of walking, and maybe that exercise and turning the gut did the trick. Immediately hit the throne room and was magnanimously rewarded. After that, as they say, the rest was easy. Wishing you an equally glorious outcome. - Shu

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer death

Posts.Content: Yes, I live in South Texas; and yes, Jalapeño peppers are a vegetable of choice. I suppose there are two ways to look at this thing: ..glass half empty; Jalapeño peppers did nothing to prevent development of prostate cancer ..glass half full; without regular Jalapeño ingestion, the cancer would have developed earlier and been more agressive. Or - maybe - Jalapeños got nothin' to do with it. Take your pick. -shu

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Mario - Take ten slow deep breaths and relax. The usual way to determine if cancer is actually present is with a biopsy - taking some random core samples by way of a spring-fired needle mounted on an ultrasound head - the whole affair inserted through the anus. This procedure is not enjoyable in any way, but is endurable, and is done locally in the urologist's office. Something to keep in mind, the biopsy is *just* a random sampling. Usually if cancer is there the biopsy will rake in some of it, but since it is just a sampling it will not give a full and complete picture. So - if you are a worrier - there you are. It's what we have to deal with. The good news: 1) prostate cancers usually grow slowly, so panic is not called for here; 2) a PSA of 2 with an intact prostate is like nothing (I am not a medical professional, but that is my take on it); and 3) re-read point #1. If the urologist says not to worry, I'd be inclined to believe him/her. But to settle your mind you could always gather up the lab reports and run them by another urologist for a second opinion. Best wishes, -shu

Posts.Title: Concerned 41 yr old PSA 2

Posts.Content: I haven't had a problem with it. Surgeon at 6 week post-op visit said, as you say, get a PSA every six months for next five years. Medicare hasn't rejected one yet. Don't see why not after radiation also. Medicare has a schedule for routine diagnostic test intervals, but if Doc orders a test more frequently for a justifiable medical reason, should be honored.

Posts.Title: PSA test frequency covered under Medicare

Posts.Content: Hello Kens - Pretty much what everyone else said. At Gleason 3+3=6 there is probably no huge rush for treatment - keeping in mind you never know what the random biopsy cores missed. At age 57 you may be wanting to get more mileage out of your prostate than I did at close to 70. That might skew the decision toward radiation if/when active treatment is needed. Sex after surgery is still good, just a lot less messy. Gives new meaning to the phrase "dry humping." But, yeah - I think most of the guys on the board here go for the surgery first. Done early, before the horse gets out of the barn and into the lymph nodes etc., by an experienced operating team, prospects for post surgery bladder control and erectile function are good. If the pathology report on the prostate shows containment, and the PSA is undetectable (<0.1) at the 6 week check, chances are very good you are clear of the cancer. But do let us know what you decide, and give us some progress checks. It's a good crew here, willing to share their stories. - shu

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Good to hear. First poop is a major event. Keep him hydrated. Stewed prunes, prune juice, fresh dates may help get things moving. It is serious surgery, so mind the instructions about lifting. Keep him walking. Best wishes for a happy pathology report - Shu P.S. About six months after my RP, Family Medicine Doc's office called. They wanted to schedule an appointment for vitamin D counseling; "Doctor says it's important for prostate health." I told them I'd be happy to show up for the counseling, but I couldn't bring my prostate 'cause I'd left that in Houston.

Posts.Title: Post-Surgery Experience

Posts.Content: Hello Kens - Pretty much what everyone else said. At Gleason 3+3=6 there is probably no huge rush for treatment - keeping in mind you never know what the random biopsy cores missed. At age 57 you may be wanting to get more mileage out of your prostate than I did at close to 70. That might skew the decision toward radiation if/when active treatment is needed. Sex after surgery is still good, just a lot less messy. Gives new meaning to the phrase "dry humping." But, yeah - I think most of the guys on the board here go for the surgery first. Done early, before the horse gets out of the barn and into the lymph nodes etc., by an experienced operating team, prospects for post surgery bladder control and erectile function are good. If the pathology report on the prostate shows containment, and the PSA is undetectable (<0.1) at the 6 week check, chances are very good you are clear of the cancer. But do let us know what you decide, and give us some progress checks. It's a good crew here, willing to share their stories. - shu

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Hi McNova - I'm thinking most here would agree at Gleason 6 that active surveillance is a reasonable choice - keeping in mind of course that the biopsy is just a random sample, there could be something more nefarious lurking undetected. Most here would agree, I think, that Gleason 7 (particularly if it's 4+3=7 rather than 3+4=7), at age 67 if your Dad is in generally good health, it's time to select and move forward with some treatment method. For us, at age 69 1/2, receiving the news of the biopsy cold, we went from zero to decision for surgery in probably less than 5 minutes. Among other considerations I wanted to get it done before I got any older, and before the Afraudable Care Act created more spread between Health Insurance and actual Health Care. Prostatectomy, either 'hands-in' or 'robotic' is actually a rather routine procedure. Best done sooner than later, before any tumor(s) gets away from the site. Yes, there is a percentage for incontinence or sexual function problems; We were in otherwise good health, just on the opposite side of the cusp from your Dad's Gleason 6, and were ready to accept the percentages. There is, of course, the alternative of radiation treatment. The decision of what, if any, treatment is of course your Father's. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Questions to ask at upcoming Dr appt

Posts.Content: Hey, Bow - Prostatectomy is serious surgery, but also *very* commonly done. A good team will have done many procecures, seen and handled just about every problem likely to come up. There is really not a lot of pain involved. Likely you will get some high power pain meds on leaving the hospital, but most of us seems to just get on with over-the-counter stuff after the first day. The catheter is mostly a non-issue. Yeah, you will have a bag strapped to your ankle for a week or so. Keep the tip of the urethra clean and lubed. Don't push too hard getting back to normal duty - there is a lot more healing needs be done inside compared to the few cuts on the surface. Give it a couple of months. Do keep up with simple walking - gets blood flowing through the area and keeps gentle stretching during healing. Urinary control and erections vary widely with individuals. We lose the urinary sphincter at the prostate, and so are left with just the pelvic floor sphincter - the same equipment as the ladies have for urinary control. If tumors are not piercing the prostate shell, a good surgery team should leave the erectile nerves with minimal trauma. If not, and erections are important, there are other means. Having got the cancer out is a major mental comfort. Best wishes for you - Shu

Posts.Title: Want the real expectation for Prostate removal

Posts.Content: Mimi - Can't speak with authority to your question of why the low PSA. With family members in both paternal and maternal lines having/had PC, I started testing early. I was surprised, but compliant, when the urologist wanted a biopsy at PSA 4.0. Glad that he did. I'd say yr husband's biopsy results are what they are. If you believe them, and have selected surgery, then focus on getting ready for that. After that, settle back and wait on the pathology report - which will be released whenever it is ready. Examining the whole prostate and other removed material, along with the 6 week post-op PSA test will give a high confidence level report on whether/or not the cancer was entirely removed. Unfortunately, the operation is not reversible. It'd be nice if we could clean up the prostate and put it back in place like the carburetor on an engine. BTW, I noticed several folks posting the size of their prostate from the path. report, so I went back and looked up my own. Comparatively rather small. Perhaps that is a factor in low PSA reading vs. Gleason score. Best wishes, - shu

Posts.Title: Low 1.7 PSA with 1.1 cm lesion

Posts.Content: What they said, mostly. As to pain post operative, you will likely be prescribed some heavy duty pain killer pills on release from the hospital. I took one or two, but found Advil was all that was needed. Most of us here, I think, were the same. Actual pain from the surgical wounds is not a worry. The CO2 gas needed to create the operating cavity was, for me, no problem at all - just a lot of farting. Shoulder pain from the position we are placed on the operating table, likewise was not an issue for me. The catheter can trigger sudden and intense bladder spasms, but keep the tip of the penis lubricated and should be no problem. After you start walking, the catheter is mostly must an annoyance to drag the bag around around and empty it, and an occasional distracting tug on your Johnson. Catheter removal is a non-issue. Slips right out like taking a whizz. First bowel movement is a major event. But about day 3 or 4 when you really start worrying, it'll all work out. Just watch what you eat - soft foods, soft fiber, stool softeners on schedule. A lot of discomforts, but not much real pain. By about day 3 you'll have figured out how to move around. After that, the problem is mostly to hold yourself back from trying too much too soon. There is a lot more healing needs to take place inside than the few surface cuts indicate. Rest and relax Monday, do the bowel purge stuff and fasting, you'll do fine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Content: Sounds like you're getting a handle on it, DogD. Ease off the liquid intake as bed-time approaches, as others have said. Coffee, tea, alcohol, etc. with caution and temperance. There will, of course, be less pressure and drip when you are supine than when vertical; but if you were not dripping or flowing as you walked from bed to toilet in yr post above, then it seems yr bod has the right idea about holding and release. Just give it time to learn and adapt. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: My take: Installing the catheter is trying to push on a rope - but you're knocked out at the time, so you don't feel it. Removing it? About as painful as taking a whizz. The usual procedure is to cut the tube that drains the urine, and use a syringe to back-fill the bladder with water. Then the tube to the positioning balloon inside the bladder is cut, deflating the balloon and allowing the entire affair to be withdrawn. Then, with a filled bladder, those in attendance get to see what degree of bladder control you have. Our Catheter Class at the hospital, day after surgery, we were told if e.g. we lived really far from any medical facility, we could just cut and pull the thing ourselves - no big deal. Local Urologist, who pulled mine, said I should not have taken the 'anaspaz' bladder spasm pill that morning, since it works by clinching what sphincter we are left with, and he wanted to be sure the path was not blocked and I *could* release urine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: Well, several hours knocked out and a prostatectomy operation is a rather traumatic insult to the body. But I figured it was better than the alternative, and decided to just go with the flow. Our experience, two years ago: I was just short of 70 yrs old, generally good health. MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston - a six hour drive from home. We booked a kitchenette room at the on-campus hotel for 10 days. Arrived Thurs evening for pre-op tests Friday, relaxed weekend, Sunday bowel purge routine, and 0530 show Monday for D-Day. Out of the OR and into the hospital room by 1400 hrs. Nobody pushed us to walk, and I certainly was not pushing myself. D+1: Slouched a short way down the hall to the scheduled moring catheter management class. Back to bed. That evening, thought about walking but just got up and stood outside the hospital room door for a while. Could feel things were getting sorted out, and projected I would be good to go after one more night. Evening attack of bladder spasm halted by application of lubricant to catheter. D+2: Up early, scrounged IV tree for support, walked with Wife to elevators and Starbucks on ground floor. Returned to minor chastisement from Deputy Surgeon for having neglected to sign out on white board in room. Discharge orders. Intern shows up to pull abdominal drain. ("When I tell you, say 'Woooooooo'". Masks weird feeling of long drain tail being drawn from gut.) Shuffle down to pharmacy for Rx meds, then to hotel room (attached to hospital). D+3: Resting in hotel room; trips to campus cafeterias and grounds, pushing scrounged wheel chair for support. D+4: Same; trips to local stores for groceries and incontinence supplies; walking unsupported. D+5: Wakeup after midnight to gut rumblings; ineffectual search for all-night pharmacy to buy laxative; back to hotel room; welcome bowel relief. Day of rest; Wife packs car. D+6: Wife drives us home; stop every hour or so for brief walk. D+9: Pre-scheduled appointment w/ local Urologist for catheter removal. (In retrospect, would have been less trouble just to cut and pull it ourselves.) YMMV - Shu

Posts.Content: Ouch. Had my share of inguinal hernia repairs; one each side in youth, bilateral laproscopic about age 56. Recovery from the DaVinci was generally smoother than the laproscopic hernia repairs, but too much heavy lifting or prolonged sitting (computer or driving) causes pain at the crease of the groin and fluid accumulation in testicles. Nothing like problem you had! You have my sympathy, Bonehead ... and best wishes. - shu

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: Apropos wound care: the umbilical scar from my prostatectomy two years ago has started to develop a small irritating red bump. This is, I suspect, a keloid area. You can Google up "keloid." It is a type of scar reaction, a permanent raised red welt, often itchy. I've got a 1x3 cm keloid under one armpit from a spider bite about five years ago. Not fun. Sweat (it's summer in South Texas, and I've been working outside) seems to promote the formation or flame-up. There are silicone patches available OTC at pharmacies, supposed to aid in formation of normal skin (rather than scar tissue) at wound sites. Manufacturer's claims are, may I say, "optimistic." But the patches do protect the area from sweat and other irritants, make it less itchy.

Posts.Title: Question on wound care & healing?

Posts.Content: Dog - For at least a decade before the prostate cancer issue I would several times a day feel an urgent need to pee, but little or nothing there. Did not happen at night during sleep. Each year. during the annual DRE+PSA visit I would pester the Doc about this, thinking it must be a bladder infection or something. No result. Problem gradually went away when Wife and I started doing some yoga exercises - notably stretching and relaxing the lower back. Suspect now that the phantom urinary problem was due to a nerve getting pinched; I have some rather traumatized discs in the lower spine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Plumbing issues

Posts.Content: Rooster - I just rolled onto a side, skidded around on the bed, dropped the knees to the floor (think traditional bedside prayer position) and pushed up. Worked after previous hernia repairs also. Ski pole should work, on carpeted floor; wouldn't try it on hard surface. Crutch or cane with rubber tip, whatever works for you. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Use snow ski poles during DaVinci surgery recovery

Posts.Content: SR - Yeah, three days is about right for the first poop - and welcome it is, when it comes! We likewise were in the hotel on the hospital campus. Had not done any study on how best to manage post-op diet, and was just packing in all the roughage, salad greens, baked beans, and stuff I could find along with some calories. Still not sure what the best management plan is, but it all worked out in the end - so to speak. Nice PSA reading. Best wishes for many more of the same. - shu

Posts.Title: 3 months after surgery

Posts.Content: My take: Installing the catheter is trying to push on a rope - but you're knocked out at the time, so you don't feel it. Removing it? About as painful as taking a whizz. The usual procedure is to cut the tube that drains the urine, and use a syringe to back-fill the bladder with water. Then the tube to the positioning balloon inside the bladder is cut, deflating the balloon and allowing the entire affair to be withdrawn. Then, with a filled bladder, those in attendance get to see what degree of bladder control you have. Our Catheter Class at the hospital, day after surgery, we were told if e.g. we lived really far from any medical facility, we could just cut and pull the thing ourselves - no big deal. Local Urologist, who pulled mine, said I should not have taken the 'anaspaz' bladder spasm pill that morning, since it works by clinching what sphincter we are left with, and he wanted to be sure the path was not blocked and I *could* release urine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: Glendy - Just want to say Welcome aboard and mention (so I read in the surgeon's handout) there are plenty of good radiation protocols for initial treatment and in cases where the patient selected that the five year "cure" rate is statistically the same as with surgery. There are particular cases where either radiation or surgery would for one reason or another be less appropriate. The folks on this board do seem to skew toward surgery, but your guy should investigate all options to make the most informed decision. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Checking in after successful surgery

Posts.Content: Sounds good to me. About the same as we did; leave some time open both before and after. MD Anderson wanted a "day prior" visit (enema, brief ultrasound to measure prostate size - information for surgeon re. size of cut needed to remove bagged gland from operating cavity). We arrived Thursday evening, had Friday afternoon and Saturday to enjoy Houston. Sunday mostly devoted to the pre-op fasting and purging schedule. Report at 0500 hours Monday. By mid-afternoon, we were out of recovery and in the hospital room. Tuesday's event was a short shuffle down the hall for a catheter training class. If the hospital had required, I could have checked out that evening, but I was looking for a morning departure so both wife and I would be more rested. Wednesday early I grabbed a loose IV tree for support and we shuffled down to Starbucks at the main cafeteria for a test hike. Then back to the room and wait around for discharge. Remainder of the week was at the hotel in the hospital campus; resting, walking around the grounds or to one of the campus cafeterias, using a wheel-chair for support. By the end of the week, a couple of car trips to nearby supermarket to proof-out seating comfort for travel. When wife had some work done at MD Anderson a couple of years previous, I had split the 300 mile return trip over two days. For me, wife got the car loaded entirely by herself, and drove all the way back. Brave soul! You will be wanting to stop at least every hour + half both to walk around a bit and get the circulation going in the abdomen and legs, and to empty the catheter bag. Don't forget to snap the drain tap closed on the bag (*really*!). Yeah, you will want to keep the seat mostly laid back. Catheter came out on D+10 at a pre-scheduled appointment with the local urologist.. Gleason 3+4=7, if in good health and generally active, you should be well placed for an uneventful recovery with no permanent incontinence or erectile problems. Best wishes - shu
Posts.Signature: Birth Year 1943; BMI 25 Dec 2010: PSA 2.8 Mar 2011: PSA 2.4 Sep 2011: PSA 2.2; free/total 12% Oct 2012: PSA 3.0; free/total 10% Apr 2013: PSA 4.0; free/total 9% Urologist notes adverse trends of both PSA and f/t ratio; calls for biopsy Jun 2013 biopsy, 12 cores: [email protected]+4=7, [email protected]+3=6, 1 pre-cancerous. Aug 2013 DaVinci RP in Houston. Aug 2013 post-op pathology: 28 grams; ..confirm Gleason 3+4=7; five tumor foci found within prostate; ..clean margins; clean seminal vesicles, clean vas dif.; clean lymph nodes; ..perineural invasion present. Oct 2013 post-op visit; PSA <0.1 ..occasional small squirt of urine with yawn or full bladder ..mr. johnson more bashful than before, but still able to stand up by himself. Posts.Title: RALP Scheduled

Posts.Content: Dog - For at least a decade before the prostate cancer issue I would several times a day feel an urgent need to pee, but little or nothing there. Did not happen at night during sleep. Each year. during the annual DRE+PSA visit I would pester the Doc about this, thinking it must be a bladder infection or something. No result. Problem gradually went away when Wife and I started doing some yoga exercises - notably stretching and relaxing the lower back. Suspect now that the phantom urinary problem was due to a nerve getting pinched; I have some rather traumatized discs in the lower spine. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: Plumbing issues

Posts.Content: Glendy - Just want to say Welcome aboard and mention (so I read in the surgeon's handout) there are plenty of good radiation protocols for initial treatment and in cases where the patient selected that the five year "cure" rate is statistically the same as with surgery. There are particular cases where either radiation or surgery would for one reason or another be less appropriate. The folks on this board do seem to skew toward surgery, but your guy should investigate all options to make the most informed decision. Best wishes - shu

Posts.Title: Plumbing issues

Posts.Content: Hmmmm. I had no major problem managing the day bag. Was important to have the tube well and properly taped to the leg to avoid annoying tugs of the penis. Maybe an advantage of being a "grower." Night bag was just too unwieldy to be mobile with. - shu

Posts.Title: Orgasms after surgery?

Posts.Content: Hello Jlynn. Welcome. You will find a bunch of guys here who have been down the path. Pratoman summed it up well for you. You have a new issue to deal with - Prostate Cancer. The good news is PC grows slowly and if detected early (as you have) may be entirely within the prostate. Prospect for a complete "cure" is very good. Thus there is no immediate call for panic nor despair, but G:3+4=7 is about the cusp between ..active surveillance (let's watch this and see how fast it's growing) and ..time to pick a treatment path and move on it. Get the recommended book, and educate yourselves. Of treatment paths, there are generally two: ..surgical removal of the prostate; ..radiation to kill the cancer on site. Hormone therapy, chemo, etc. are appropriate if cancer cells have escaped the prostate and lodged elsewhere in the body. With surgery the urethra is cut where the prostate joins the base of the bladder, and again immediately below the prostate. The loose ends of the urethra are sewn together; the prostate (and cancer) go to the lab. This leaves the guy without the urinary control gate that was in the prostate but still with the gate in the pelvic floor. In the words of one of my Urologists, "you will piss like a woman." Most men already use that muscle, or soon learn how. There are two nerves, one running each side of the prostate, needed in erectile function. If the cancer is not at the outer shell of the prostate, a good surgeon can peel these away leaving them just temporarily stunned. Thus with the surgical path there are immediate issues of incontinence and erectile function, but both with very good prospect of recovery if the cancer is found early and the surgical team is well practiced. Of course with the prostate gone there is no seminal fluid. Sex is different after surgery - mostly, a lot less messy. Your priority in any event should be: 1) deal with the cancer; 2) be continent; 3) sexual function. Radiation, I cannot speak to other than to say ..there are different types: radio-isotope seeds placed in the prostate, externally applied beam radiation, etc. ..the cancer "cure" rate is about equivalent between surgery and radiation; ..radiation leaves the prostate in place but scarred - urinary and erectile function are not immediately affected, but problems may develop as areas of scarring grow. We picked surgery because ..the pathologist gets the prostate for a good look as to whether the cancer was contained or not; ..with the prostate gone, PSA drop to undetectable strongly suggests no cancerous prostate cells have escaped. As Pratoman said: educate yourselves, make your decision, and don't look back. Best wishes - Shu

As Pratoman said: educate yourselves, make your decision, and don't look back. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Content: Maternal grandfather died of PC. Father, paternal uncle, older brother were treated and cured. Younger brother is doing AS. Started annual PSA and DRE in birth month at age 45. Advanced prostate cancer is no fun. If found early and treated, cure rate is high. PSA and DRE are simple, highly effective tools for early detection. DUH!

Posts.Title: Family History?

Posts.Content: Hello Jlynn. Welcome. You will find a bunch of guys here who have been down the path. Pratoman summed it up well for you. You have a new issue to deal with - Prostate Cancer. The good news is PC grows slowly and if detected early (as you have) may be entirely within the prostate. Prospect for a complete "cure" is very good. Thus there is no immediate call for panic nor despair, but G:3+4=7 is about the cusp between ..active surveillance (let's watch this and see how fast it's growing) and ..time to pick a treatment path and move on it. Get the recommended book, and educate yourselves. Of treatment paths, there are generally two: ..surgical removal of the prostate; ..radiation to kill the cancer on site. Hormone therapy, chemo, etc. are appropriate if cancer cells have escaped the prostate and lodged elsewhere in the body. With surgery the urethra is cut where the prostate joins the base of the bladder, and again immediately below the prostate. The loose ends of the urethra are sewn together; the prostate (and cancer) go to the lab. This leaves the guy without the urinary control gate that was in the prostate but still with the gate in the pelvic floor. In the words of one of my Urologists, "you will piss like a woman." Most men already use that muscle, or soon learn how. There are two nerves, one running each side of the prostate, needed in erectile function. If the cancer is not at the outer shell of the prostate, a good surgeon can peel these away leaving them just temporarily stunned. Thus with the surgical path there are immediate issues of incontinence and erectile function, but both with very good prospect of recovery if the cancer is found early and the surgical team is well practiced. Of course with the prostate gone there is no seminal fluid. Sex is different after surgery - mostly, a lot less messy. Your priority in any event should be: 1) deal with the cancer; 2) be continent; 3) sexual function. Radiation, I cannot speak to other than to say ..there are different types: radio-isotope seeds placed in the prostate, externally applied beam radiation, etc. ..the cancer "cure" rate is about equivalent between surgery and radiation; ..radiation leaves the prostate in place but scarred - urinary and erectile function are not immediately affected, but problems may develop as areas of scarring grow. We picked surgery because ..the pathologist gets the prostate for a good look as to whether the cancer was contained or not; ..with the prostate gone, PSA drop to undetectable strongly suggests no cancerous prostate cells have escaped. As Pratoman said: educate yourselves, make your decision, and don't look back. Best wishes - Shu

Posts.Title: 55 yr old husband just diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Welcome aboard, tripple Fox. My thoughts: Gleason 6, active surveillance a reasonable option. Large lesion identified near bladder, time to move on it! One of my classmates described himself as an honorary member of our club. He had bladder cancer, prostate was removed along with bladder. You do not want an artificial bladder. I was 69 1/2 when we "got the news" of my own biopsy, immediatly opting for surgery. It was not unexpected, given my family history, In a way, it was welcome. Fact or not, we sensed that treatment availability would begin to close down after age 70 and as the Affordable Care Act came more on line. I am retired military with Medicare and Tricare. Very best wishes to you - Shu

Posts.Title: Surgery Scheduled for January

Posts.Content: Hiwayjunkie - The "long term effects" of prostatectomy that concern you probably are urinary control and erectile function. At my six week post-op visit both these were well within the range which, at the time the decision for the daVinci procedure was made, I was willing to accept. The skill of the surgical team is important in both areas, as is the general health of the patient. If the tumor(s) have invaded the erectile nerve(s) then removal of the cancer, or killing in place by radiation, will necessarily harm the nerves and therefore erectile function - even in the hands of the most skilled team. You see posts on the board from men who struggle with problems of incontinence, erectile function, or both. I suspect the average post surgical outcome is closer to my own. There is a third "long term effect" of prostatectomy which should be your primary concern. That is eradication of the cancer. Issues in the immediate weeks following surgery are, as I and others have noted, more a convergence of discomforts (bloat, bruising/aches, bowel function, dealing with the catheter bag) than a matter of real pain. Best wishes to you - Shu

DoctorRecommended.Sample: You mention Texas. When the local urologist delivered the biopsy news, he said ..bone scan or other tests for metastasis not recommended, as biopsy suggested cancer detected early and contained; ..some form of treatment was indicated, either radiation or surgery, surgery being either open or robotic; ..we were welcome to look for a second opinion on the biopsy, MD Anderson in Houston sometimes would do that....When the local urologist delivered the biopsy news, he said ..bone scan or other tests for metastasis not recommended, as biopsy suggested cancer detected early and contained; ..some form of treatment was indicated, either radiation or surgery, surgery being either open or robotic; ..we were welcome to look for a second opinion on the biopsy, MD Anderson in Houston sometimes would do that. At that point, wife and I looked at eachother....
